headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Yolanda, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. It's nnow my pleas
componenttext:
Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Yolanda, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
It's nnow my pleasure to turn the call over to Mr. John Locke. You may begin.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's fourth quarter 2015 earnings conference call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our Executive Vice President of Refining Operations and Engineering; Jay Browning, our Executive Vice President and General Counsel; and several other members of Valero senior management team. If you have not received the earnings release and would like a copy, you can find one on our website at valero.com. Also attached to the earnings release are tables that provide additional financial information on our business segments. If you have any questions after reviewing these tables, please feel free to contact our Investor Relations team after the call. 
I would like to direct your attention to the forward-looking statement disclaimer contained in the press release. In summary, it says that statements in the press release and on this conference call that state the company's or management's expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions under federal securities laws. There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations, including those we've described in our filings with the SEC. 
Now I will turn the call over to Joe for a few opening remarks.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. The fourth quarter and full year 2015 were really great for Valero. We operated safely and reliably, achieving our lowest ever employee injury rate in refining and reaching an annual average refinery utiliza
componenttext:
Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. The fourth quarter and full year 2015 were really great for Valero. We operated safely and reliably, achieving our lowest ever employee injury rate in refining and reaching an annual average refinery utilization rates of 95%. The market were favorable during the quarter. Domestic product demand grew supported by a lower pulp price in sour crude discounts relative to breath were attractive to our highly complex refining system. While distillates margins were pressured during unseasonably warm weather in North America and Europe, distillates demand in Latin America remained robust. In fact, we exported record volumes of distillates and gasoline in the fourth quarter. 
We continue to execute well on our fourth quarter. In the quarter, we successfully commissioned the new Corpus Christi crude unit, the Port Arthur gas hydrocracker expansion and the McKee crude unit expansion. Our Québec city refinery also began receiving crude via Enbridge's Line 9B. We exercised our option with Plains All American to acquire 50% interest in the Diamond crude oil pipeline project. Once completed, this project will connect Cushing with Memphis and provide us with crude optionality and long-term cost savings versus sourcing crude oil from St. James. Additionally, Valero Energy Partners continues to execute its growth strategy and Valero GP's interest in VLP reached the highest splits with the distribution increase we announced earlier this week. 
We also continue to advance our refining growth strategy. Construction of the Houston crude unit remains on schedule with startup plans in the second quarter of 2016 and earlier this month, our Board of Directors approved the Houston alkylation project. This project is estimated to cost $300 million and is expected to be completed in the first half of 2019. 
And finally, regarding cash returns to stockholders. We paid out 80% of our 2015 adjusted net income, exceeding the 75% annual payout target, further demonstrating our belief in Valero's earning potential. Last week, our Board of Directors approved a 20% increase in the regular quarterly dividend to $0.60 per share or $2.40 annually. 
With that, John, I'll hand it back over to you.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Joe. Moving on to the results. We reported fourth quarter 2015 adjusted net income from continuing operations of $862 million or $1.79 per share versus $952 million or $1.83 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014. Actual net income from
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Joe. Moving on to the results. We reported fourth quarter 2015 adjusted net income from continuing operations of $862 million or $1.79 per share versus $952 million or $1.83 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014. Actual net income from continuing operations was $298 million or $0.62 per share, which compares to $1.2 billion or $2.22 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014. Please refer to the reconciliations of actual to adjusted amounts as shown in the financial tables that the company released. 
For 2015, we reported adjusted net income from continuing operations of $4.6 billion for $9.24 per share compared to $3.5 billion or $6.68 per share for 2014. Actual net income from continuing operations was $4 billion or $7.99 per share in 2015 versus $3.7 billion or $6.97 per share in 2014. Fourth quarter 2015 refining segment adjusted operating income of $1.5 billion was in line with the fourth quarter of 2014. Stronger gasoline other product margins combined with higher refining throughput volumes were offset by lower distillates and petrochemical margins and lower discounts for sweet crude oils relative to Brent crude oil. 
Refining throughput volumes averaged 2.9 million barrels per day, which was 34,000 barrels per day higher than the fourth quarter of 2014. Our refineries operated at 97% throughput capacity utilization in the fourth quarter of 2015. Refining cash operating expenses of $3.47 per barrel or $0.29 per barrel lower than the fourth quarter of 2014, largely driven by favorable property tax settlements and reserve adjustments at lower energy cost. 
The ethanol segment generated $37 million of adjusted operating income in the fourth quarter of 2015, versus $154 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, due primarily to lower gross margin per gallon driven by a decline in ethanol prices versus relatively stable corn prices. For the fourth quarter of 2015, general and administrative expenses excluding corporate depreciation were $206 million and net interest expense was $107 million. Depreciation and amortization expense was $494 million and the effective tax rate was 28% in the fourth quarter of 2015. The effective tax rate was lower than expected due primarily to a reduction in the statutory tax rate in the United Kingdom and the settlement of income tax audits in the United States. 
With respect to our balance sheet at quarter end. Total debt was $7.4 billion and cash and temporary cash investments were $4.1 billion, of which $81 million was held by VLP. Valero's debt to capitalization ratio, net of $2 billion in cash, was 20%. We have $5.6 billion of available liquidity, excluding cash. Cash flows in the fourth quarter included $732 million of capital investments, of which $164 million was for turnarounds in catalyst and $136 million was for investment in the Diamond pipeline. 
For 2015, capital investment included $1.4 billion for stay-in business and $1 billion for growth. We returned $1 billion in cash for stockholders in the fourth quarter, which included $240 million in dividend payments and $767 million for the purchase of 11.1 million shares of Valero common stock. For 2015, we purchased 44.9 million shares for $2.8 billion. 
For 2016, we maintain our guidance of $2.6 billion for capital investments, including turnarounds, catalyst, joint venture and strategic investments. This consists of approximately $1.6 billion for stay-in business and $1 billion for growth. For modeling our first quarter operations, we expect throughput volumes to fall between the following ranges: U.S. Gulf Coast at 1.61 million to 1.66 million barrels per day; U.S. Mid-Continent at 430,000 to 450,000 barrels per day; U.S. West Coast at 245,000 to 265,000 barrels per day; and North Atlantic at 465,000 to 485,000 barrels per day. We expect refining cash operating expenses in the first quarter to be approximately $3.85 per barrel. 
Our ethanol segment is expected to produce a total of 3.8 million gallons per day in the first quarter. Operating expenses should average $0.37 per gallon, which includes $0.05 per gallon for noncash costs, such as depreciation and amortization. We expect G&A expenses, excluding corporate depreciation for the first quarter, to be around $175 million and that interest expense should be about $110 million. Total depreciation and amortization expense should be approximately $470 million and our effective tax rate is expected to be around 32%. 
That concludes our opening remarks. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Overall, we've seen very good spreads between medium sours and light and heavy sours as well. And certainly, the uranium production coming online will put further pressure on those differentials. I think we see several things in the market. As you know, t
componenttext: Overall, we've seen very good spreads between medium sours and light and heavy sours as well. And certainly, the uranium production coming online will put further pressure on those differentials. I think we see several things in the market. As you know, the increase in productions medium sour barrels into Gulf. You see Gulf of Mexico deepwater medium sour production rising. At the same time, we're seeing some of the light sweet production falling off here in the United States with leading to very good differentials. I think the other thing that a fundamental shift is where fuel had been trading around 80% of Brent. It's not trading around 60% of Brent, which should mean that we would expect to see good medium sour and heavy sour differentials throughout the year. I think the other thing for us, the uranium production, of course, we won't be running any those barrels, but we do think the market rebalances and makes some additional heavy and medium grade available to us and from Latin America.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Joe, Lane and Gary, you guys unique window into what's happening from a product demand perspective. It's one of the big debates in the market right now. Can you talk about what the export market looks like from our perspective for diesel and gasoline?
componenttext: So Joe, Lane and Gary, you guys unique window into what's happening from a product demand perspective. It's one of the big debates in the market right now. Can you talk about what the export market looks like from our perspective for diesel and gasoline? And then to piggyback off of that, you see for weeks now these gasoline builds in the DOEs, is that consistent with what you're seeing on the ground?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary. I think we continue to see very good export demand for our products. As Joe mentioned, we had record volumes in the fourth quarter. We continue to see good demand for both distillate and gasoline abroad. Our volumes remain very strong. We're
componenttext: This is Gary. I think we continue to see very good export demand for our products. As Joe mentioned, we had record volumes in the fourth quarter. We continue to see good demand for both distillate and gasoline abroad. Our volumes remain very strong. We're moving a lot of products over the rags. We've seen the domestic demand for our product as well. Certainly, I think when you get this early in the year, it's kind of hard to dissect the DOE data. We've seen the large builds as well. Some of the data looks a little suspect. I think we've seen a lot of weather issues in the Gulf that our belief may have been that it's hindered some of the waterborne barrels from being able to leave due to fog and weather that we've had in the Gulf. And then Mississippi River flooding also has hindered some of the refineries along the rivers, the ability to clear those barrels as well. I think we're just too early to really do to get a good view of what demand is going to look like, but everything from us, our perspective looks good.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: The fundamental for strong demand are still there. There's no question about that. I mean, we continue to have prices that are very attractive at the Street. And then there's a lot of data that's coming out recently on vehicle miles traveled being up and
componenttext: The fundamental for strong demand are still there. There's no question about that. I mean, we continue to have prices that are very attractive at the Street. And then there's a lot of data that's coming out recently on vehicle miles traveled being up and also on auto sales being skewed towards larger SUVs and light heavy truck. So again, as Gary said, it seems like every January, Neil, we find ourselves in a situation where we're looking at the year and everybody's trying to figure out, oh gee, it's over and this demand is going to be totally eroded. And as he said, I think it's a little early to tell. But fundamentally, it looks like things should go well for us going forward.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Joe. I appreciate it. For Valero, our appetite for midstream M&A and M&A in general has changed. We continue to look at opportunities, particularly those that support the earnings growth that we continue to achieve in our core business. The good n
componenttext: Thanks, Joe. I appreciate it. For Valero, our appetite for midstream M&A and M&A in general has changed. We continue to look at opportunities, particularly those that support the earnings growth that we continue to achieve in our core business. The good news is we have a great portfolio of significant earnings capability as we demonstrated in '15. More specific to VLP, VLP hasn't reached the size where it can execute most of the M&A transactions on its own. But we do continue to evaluate opportunities there as well. But as we said before, we remain committed to VLP's drop-down growth strategy and we're not interested in a step out transaction that would change VLP's risk profile or its growth story.

That's the big change in our system. Heavy sours are about the same.

Does the mix even though you already have a very, very strong balance sheet to maybe you deny a part of the free cash flow maybe 20% or so to further strengthen the balance sheet. I think that we all need for the up-and-down while I'm bullish on the market. I could be wrong. And that we have seen what happened to everyone was bullish in 2007 and then the bottom fell off because of the economy. So should we actually take maybe a slightly different view at this point just as a safe thought to ensure that we view up some additional cushion, even though you're balance sheet is already remarkably strong. But if cash flow cut by half, then maybe that will allow you even to have better the strike and take the opportunity everyone this week.

componenttext: And then Joe, just curious that I think that some of the other company and this look like some retail as it maybe become cheaper. If you're looking at your portfolio, does it make sense that if the entry point is right for you to reenter into retail by doing so that can maybe that cushion you against or hedge against any win cause increase or debt more direct to your own refi product? Or that this is going back into that business?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, that's a good question. We look at it periodically. The retail business is materially different from the refining business and you know that. I mean, we're capital intensive and fewer people and the retail business is people intensive. And when we l
componenttext: Paul, that's a good question. We look at it periodically. The retail business is materially different from the refining business and you know that. I mean, we're capital intensive and fewer people and the retail business is people intensive. And when we look at it, I think our view would generally be that we don't need to control the retail outlet to be able to be a very good supplier into that market. And so frankly, what we're focused on is further extending our wholesale business where we could have contractual relationships and support the Valero brand at the Street from the wholesale side rather than from a direct retail operation. If you reflect back on our retail volumes when we owned CST in the thousand or so sites in the sites in Canada, the volume we moved through them was about 125,000 barrels a day. And when you look at that as its order of magnitude relative to the total motor fuel that Valero's producing, it's a very small percentage. So it would take a real huge step for us to have any kind of material presence to really allow us to hedge the benefits associated with owning retail directly. So I don't know that -- unless there was really something that was just incredibly good or allowed us to sustain our contractual relationships with customers, I don't see us reentering that market in the retail business.

componenttext: This is Gary. We see that as long as we have a strong gasoline market and we have length in sub-octane blend component like naphtha, the gasoline pull is going to try to draw naphtha in and it's going to mean octane is fairly expensive. And so we expect to see alkaline values very strong again this summer. And I don't see anything on the horizon that really makes me to believe that's going to change anytime soon.

componenttext: Okay. But maybe can you -- can you give any thoughts in terms of how you see light sweet depths, whether it's Brent TI or LSTI evolving over the next 3 to 6 months? Are we going to need to see a widening of those spreads in order to clear cushion and incentivize imports? And in particular, I was kind of curious given the fact that you backed out 400,000 barrels a day of Lower 48 light sweet crude system, just generally how you've seen -- what your outlook is for those light sweet differentials going forward over the course of this year.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary. I think over time, LLS and Brent trade is pretty close to parity. But I think we did have a lot of volatility between the grades as the year goes on. So you can see LLS got paying premium for LLS over brand. So we started importing foreign l
componenttext: This is Gary. I think over time, LLS and Brent trade is pretty close to parity. But I think we did have a lot of volatility between the grades as the year goes on. So you can see LLS got paying premium for LLS over brand. So we started importing foreign light sweet, you have inventory gains here in the U.S., which I think LLS was too expensive. So then LLS will be discarded. And I think we'll go to that volatility for the 6 months where at least receiving in out domestic light sweet production into our fine system.

componenttext: Yes, so overall, if you look at foreign light sweet barrels versus an Eagle Ford or Bakken type barrel, the naphtha yield from West African Saharan barrel is about the same as Bakken or Eagle Ford. So in terms of refining yield, it's not significantly different whether we're running that West African barrel or we're running at domestic light sweet barrel.

componenttext: Yes. For mediums heavy barrel, it would, except for most of the refiners were running those barrels are very high complexity refining assets. And again, we don't see much of a yield difference with the complexity of our refineries when we're running a heavier diet. The only thing that we can get into, as we go heavy in some of our plants, it can lower utilization some. So we get a lower effect by running light sweet. And some of our refineries. So we have every incentive to run much heavier crude diet, it can mean that we're running slightly lower crude rate at some of those plants.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Gary Simmons. Overall, I think if you drive distillate demand, it's weather and then it's economic activity. And thus far, both in the U.S. and in Northwest Europe, we've had warmer winters than what we've historically had. And so it's led to lowe
componenttext: This is Gary Simmons. Overall, I think if you drive distillate demand, it's weather and then it's economic activity. And thus far, both in the U.S. and in Northwest Europe, we've had warmer winters than what we've historically had. And so it's led to lower distillate demand. So in terms of how do we correct from here, I think a lot of the correction gets back to some of this low complexity refining capacity with discounted fuel pricing, I think we'll see some economic run cuts. Some of that low complexity capacity that will bring the distillate market back into balance.

componenttext: Circling back to VLP. I'm just curious, we all know the uncertainty in the turmoil in the capital markets, but it seems like the strategy is basically unchanged and you have 55% of the growth in 2016 in terms of budget going into VLP. At what point do you think about that? And maybe re-examine the pace of growth, given that the market doesn't necessarily seem to be rewarding growth as much as it once was?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We'll continue to -- right now, our plan is to do the $1 billion, but we'll continue to examine and monitor the markets as we move through the year. I mean, it's very challenging right now. We do have our revolver that we could use as a financing source f
componenttext: We'll continue to -- right now, our plan is to do the $1 billion, but we'll continue to examine and monitor the markets as we move through the year. I mean, it's very challenging right now. We do have our revolver that we could use as a financing source for some of the drops. So the bank market seems to build more attractive than the capital markets at this point in time.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, let me just add to what Mike said though. The capital that we are investing in logistics assets, the Valero Energy, are assets that can be dropped to VLP. So we'll continue to build the droppable EBITDA base. But the motivation behind it and we've s
componenttext: Brad, let me just add to what Mike said though. The capital that we are investing in logistics assets, the Valero Energy, are assets that can be dropped to VLP. So we'll continue to build the droppable EBITDA base. But the motivation behind it and we've shared this before, the motivation behind Valero investing in logistics assets are projects that benefit Valero's core business. It's core refining business, projects that help us all to optimize our operations. And we're not taking flyers on projects that we wouldn't be willing to commit contractually long term to. And so again, the things we're investing in today, for example, the Diamond Pipeline. I mean, the is going to be a direct benefit to the Memphis refinery and provide crude optionality there that they don't currently have today. So this is -- it's a long game and even though markets are challenged right now, I don't think we should sit here and throw the baby out with the birth water and totally redirect strategies to try to accommodate it. The other thing that Mike has mentioned is that VLP is in a great position. They've got a very high coverage ratios to maintain distribution growth with the targets we talked about is not going to be an issue. And here, again, we're running the business to continue to improve the business and drive EPS growth at VLO and VLP is going to go along for the ride. So anyway, it's just a little more color.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Yolanda, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.It's now my pleasur
componenttext:
Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Yolanda, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
It's now my pleasure to turn the call over to Mr. John Locke. You may begin.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our Executive Vice President of Refining Operations and Engineering; Jay Browning, our Executive Vice President and General Counsel; and several other members of Valero senior management team. If you have not received the earnings release and would like a copy, you can find one on our website at valero.com. Also attached to the earnings release are tables that provide additional financial information on our business segments. If you have any questions after reviewing these tables, please feel free to contact our Investor Relations team after the call.
I would like to direct your attention to the forward-looking statement disclaimer contained in the press release. In summary, it says that statements in the press release and on this conference call that state the company's or management's expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions under federal securities laws. There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations, including those we've described in our filings with the SEC.
Now I will turn the call over to Joe for a few opening remarks.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone.The fourth quarter and full year 2015 were really great for Valero. We operated safely and reliably, achieving our lowest ever employee injury rate in refining and reaching an annual average refinery utiliz
componenttext:
Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone.
The fourth quarter and full year 2015 were really great for Valero. We operated safely and reliably, achieving our lowest ever employee injury rate in refining and reaching an annual average refinery utilization rate of 95%. The markets were favorable during the quarter. Domestic product demand grew supported by lower pulp prices and sour crude discounts relative to the breadth were attractive to our highly complex refining system. While distillate margins were pressured during unseasonably warm weather in North America and Europe, distillate demand in Latin America remained robust. In fact, we exported record volumes of distillate and gasoline in the fourth quarter.
We continue to execute well on our projects. In the quarter, we successfully commissioned the new Corpus Christi crude unit, the Port Arthur gas-oil hydrocracker expansion and the McKee crude unit expansion. Our Québec City refinery also began receiving crude via Enbridge's Line 9B. We exercised our option with Plains All American to acquire a 50% interest in the Diamond crude oil pipeline project. Once completed, this project will connect Cushing with Memphis and provide us with crude optionality and long-term cost savings versus sourcing crude oil from St. James. Additionally, Valero Energy Partners continues to execute its growth strategy, and Valero GP's interest in VLP reached the highest splits with the distribution increase we announced earlier this week.
We also continue to advance our refining growth strategy. Construction of the Houston crude unit remains on schedule with startup planned in the second quarter of 2016, and earlier this month, our Board of Directors approved the Houston alkylation project. This project is estimated to cost $300 million and is expected to be completed in the first half of 2019.
And finally, regarding cash returns to stockholders, we paid out 80% of our 2015 adjusted net income, exceeding the 75% annual payout target. Further demonstrating our belief in Valero's earning potential, last week, our Board of Directors approved a 20% increase in the regular quarterly dividend to $0.60 per share or $2.40 annually.
With that, John, I'll hand it back over to you.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Joe.Moving on to the results. We reported fourth quarter 2015 adjusted net income from continuing operations of $862 million or $1.79 per share versus $952 million or $1.83 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014. Actual net income fro
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Joe.
Moving on to the results. We reported fourth quarter 2015 adjusted net income from continuing operations of $862 million or $1.79 per share versus $952 million or $1.83 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014. Actual net income from continuing operations was $298 million or $0.62 per share, which compares to $1.2 billion or $2.22 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014. Please refer to the reconciliations of actual to adjusted amounts as shown in the financial tables that the accompany our release.
For 2015, we reported adjusted net income from continuing operations of $4.6 billion or $9.24 per share compared to $3.5 billion or $6.68 per share for 2014. Actual net income from continuing operations was $4 billion or $7.99 per share in 2015 versus $3.7 billion or $6.97 per share in 2014. Fourth quarter 2015 refining segment adjusted operating income of $1.5 billion was in line with the fourth quarter of 2014. Stronger gasoline and other product margins combined with higher refining throughput volumes were offset by lower distillate and petrochemical margins and lower discounts for sweet crude oils relative to Brent crude oil.
Refining throughput volumes averaged 2.9 million barrels per day, which was 34,000 barrels per day higher than the fourth quarter of 2014. Our refineries operated at 97% throughput capacity utilization in the fourth quarter of 2015. Refining cash operating expenses of $3.47 per barrel or $0.29 per barrel lower than the fourth quarter of 2014, largely driven by favorable property tax settlements and reserve adjustments and lower energy cost.
The ethanol segment generated $37 million of adjusted operating income in the fourth quarter of 2015 versus $154 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, due primarily to lower gross margin per gallon driven by a decline in ethanol prices versus relatively stable corn prices. For the fourth quarter of 2015, general and administrative expenses excluding corporate depreciation were $206 million, and net interest expense was $107 million. Depreciation and amortization expense was $494 million, and the effective tax rate was 28% in the fourth quarter of 2015. The effective tax rate was lower than expected due primarily to a reduction in the statutory tax rate in the United Kingdom and the settlement of income tax audits in the United States.
With respect to our balance sheet at quarter end, total debt was $7.4 billion, and cash and temporary cash investments were $4.1 billion, of which $81 million was held by VLP. Valero's debt to capitalization ratio, net of $2 billion in cash, was 20%. We have $5.6 billion of available liquidity, excluding cash. Cash flows in the fourth quarter included $732 million of capital investments, of which $164 million was for turnaround and catalyst, and $136 million was for investment in the Diamond pipeline.
For 2015, capital investment included $1.4 billion for stay-in-business and $1 billion for growth. We returned $1 billion in cash for our stockholders in the fourth quarter, which included $240 million in dividend payments and $767 million for the purchase of 11.1 million shares of Valero common stock. For 2015, we purchased 44.9 million shares for $2.8 billion.
For 2016, we maintain our guidance of $2.6 billion for capital investments, including turnarounds, catalyst, joint venture and strategic investments. This consists of approximately $1.6 billion for stay-in-business and $1 billion for growth. For modeling our first quarter operations, we expect throughput volumes to fall between the following ranges: U.S. Gulf Coast at 1.61 million to 1.66 million barrels per day; U.S. Mid-Continent at 430,000 to 450,000 barrels per day; U.S. West Coast at 245,000 to 265,000 barrels per day; and North Atlantic at 465,000 to 485,000 barrels per day. We expect refining cash operating expenses in the first quarter to be approximately $3.85 per barrel.
Our ethanol segment is expected to produce a total of 3.8 million gallons per day in the first quarter. Operating expenses should average $0.37 per gallon, which includes $0.05 per gallon for noncash costs, such as depreciation and amortization. We expect G&A expenses, excluding corporate depreciation for the first quarter, to be around $175 million, and net interest expense should be about $110 million. Total depreciation and amortization expense should be approximately $470 million, and our effective tax rate is expected to be around 32%.
That concludes our opening remarks. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Secondly, just maybe, if you don't mind sharing some thoughts around light-heavy spreads into '16, and I guess what I'm thinking especially in light of Iranian barrels coming to market that could potentially displace other barrels globally since like mayb
componenttext: Secondly, just maybe, if you don't mind sharing some thoughts around light-heavy spreads into '16, and I guess what I'm thinking especially in light of Iranian barrels coming to market that could potentially displace other barrels globally since like maybe that would have an indirect benefit to Valero, given your leverage to Gulf Coast and heavy processing.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Blake, this is Gary Simmons. Overall, yes, we've seen very good spreads between the medium sours and light and heavy sours as well. And certainly, the uranium production coming online will put further pressure on those differentials. I think we see s
componenttext: Yes, Blake, this is Gary Simmons. Overall, yes, we've seen very good spreads between the medium sours and light and heavy sours as well. And certainly, the uranium production coming online will put further pressure on those differentials. I think we see several things in the market. As you know, the increase in OPEC productions put in medium sour barrels into the Gulf. You see Gulf of Mexico deepwater medium sour production rising. At the same time, we're seeing some of the light sweet production falling off here in the United States with leading to very good differentials. I think the other thing that a fundamental shift is where fuel had been trading around 80% of Brent. It's now trading around 60% of Brent, which should mean that we would expect to see good medium sour and heavy sour differentials throughout the year. I think the other thing for us, the uranium production, of course, we won't be running any of those barrels, but we do think the market rebalances and makes some additional heavy and medium grades available from us -- to us from Latin America.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Joe, Lane and Gary, you guys have a unique window into what's happening from a product demand perspective. It's one of the big debates in their own markets right now. Can you talk about what the export markets looks like from your perspective for diese
componenttext: So Joe, Lane and Gary, you guys have a unique window into what's happening from a product demand perspective. It's one of the big debates in their own markets right now. Can you talk about what the export markets looks like from your perspective for diesel and gasoline? And then to piggyback off of that, you see four weeks now these gasoline builds in the DOEs, is that consistent with what you're seeing on the ground?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Neil, this is Gary. I think we continue to see very good export demand for our products. As Joe mentioned, we had record volumes in the fourth quarter. We continue to see good demand for both distillate and gasoline abroad. Our rack volumes remain ve
componenttext: Yes, Neil, this is Gary. I think we continue to see very good export demand for our products. As Joe mentioned, we had record volumes in the fourth quarter. We continue to see good demand for both distillate and gasoline abroad. Our rack volumes remain very strong. We're moving a lot of products over the racks. We've seen good domestic demand for our product as well. Certainly, I think when you get this early in the year, it's kind of hard to dissect the DOE data. We've seen the large builds as well. Some of the data does looks a little suspect. I think we've seen a lot of weather issues in the Gulf that our belief may have been that it's hindered some of the waterborne barrels from being able to leave due to fog and weather that we've had in the Gulf. And the Mississippi River flooding also has hindered some of the refineries along the rivers, the ability to clear those barrels as well. I think we're just too early to really get a good view of what demand's going to look like, but everything from us, our perspective looks good.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the fundamental, I think, for strong demand are still there. There's no question about that. I mean, we continue to have prices that are very attractive at The Street. And then there's a lot of data that's coming out recently on vehicle miles travele
componenttext: Yes, the fundamental, I think, for strong demand are still there. There's no question about that. I mean, we continue to have prices that are very attractive at The Street. And then there's a lot of data that's coming out recently on vehicle miles traveled being up and also on auto sales being skewed towards larger SUVs and light heavy trucks. So again, as Gary said, it seems like every January, Neil, we find ourselves in a situation where we're looking at the year, and everybody's trying to figure out, oh gee, it's just over and this demand is going to be totally eroded. And as he said, I think it's just a little early to tell. But fundamentally, it looks like things should go well for us going forward.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Joe. I appreciate it. For Valero, our appetite for midstream M&A and M&A in general hasn't changed. We continue to look at opportunities, particularly those that support the earnings growth that we continue to achieve in our core business. Th
componenttext: Yes. Thanks, Joe. I appreciate it. For Valero, our appetite for midstream M&A and M&A in general hasn't changed. We continue to look at opportunities, particularly those that support the earnings growth that we continue to achieve in our core business. The good news is we have a great portfolio of significant earnings capability as we demonstrated in '15. More specific to VLP, VLP hasn't reached the size where it can execute most of the M&A transactions on its own. But we do continue to evaluate opportunities there as well. But as we said before, we remain committed to VLP's drop-down growth strategy, and we're not interested in a step out transaction that would change VLP's risk profile or its growth story.

componenttext: Right. And then but the uptick quarter-to-quarter on overall heavy and medium sour runs, I mean, where could that be? And I'm sure that's an average number, so I'm just trying to get a sense of if you're kind of max flexed at this point or where we could -- where do we take that?

componenttext: Yes. If I could give you, yes, a little color on that, Evan. I'll take the topper out so you can kind of have an apples-to-apples comparison. If you take the toppers out between last quarter and where we are today, we backed out about 400,000 barrels a day of lower 48 domestic light sweet crude, and we've replaced that with medium sour grades and foreign light sweet imports. That's the big change in our system. Heavy sours are about the same.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, actually this is for you, I'm going to offer from the other angle on the balance sheet. The last several years that you guys have done phenomenally well, both operationally and financially, and also there was return to shareholder. I'm just curious
componenttext: Mike, actually this is for you, I'm going to offer from the other angle on the balance sheet. The last several years that you guys have done phenomenally well, both operationally and financially, and also there was return to shareholder. I'm just curious then, has the cash flow remained strong at this point? Does it make sense even though you already have a very, very strong balance sheet to maybe utilize a part of the free cash flow, maybe 20% or so, to further strengthen the balance sheet? I think that we all live through the up-and-down. While I'm bullish on the market, I could be wrong. And that we have seen what happened to everyone was bullish in 2007 and then the bottom fell off because of the economy. So should we actually take maybe a slightly different view at this point just as a safe thought to ensure that we view up some additional cushion, even though you're balance sheet is already remarkably strong? But if cash flow cut by half, then maybe that will allow you to even have better opportunity to strike and take the opportunity everyone this week.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's quite a question, Paul. Yes, I remember those days very well. Our balance sheet is very strong, and we intend to keep it that way. If you're suggesting that we take -- that we build cash here, our current focus is to continue to look for oppo
componenttext: Okay. That's quite a question, Paul. Yes, I remember those days very well. Our balance sheet is very strong, and we intend to keep it that way. If you're suggesting that we take -- that we build cash here, our current focus is to continue to look for opportunity to grow our business and increase our earnings per share. But if you're suggesting that we prepay some debt, the majority of our remaining debt contains [indiscernible] provisions that make those prepayments less than compelling.

componenttext: No. I don't think at this time that, that's what we'll be doing. I think we can execute on our cash strategy and all that [indiscernible] as I said earlier without levering up the balance sheet.

componenttext: And then Joe, just curious that with -- I think that some of the other company in distress and look like some retail [indiscernible] maybe become cheaper. If you're looking at your portfolio, does it make sense that if your -- the entry point is right for you to reenter into retail by doing so that can maybe that cushion you against or the hedge against any win cause increase or that [indiscernible] more outlet, direct outlet to your own refi product? Or that this is winning only the interest that going back into that business?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now, Paul, that's a good question. We look at it periodically. The retail business is materially different from the refining business, and you know that. I mean, we're finance capital intensive and fewer people, and the retail business is people intensive
componenttext: Now, Paul, that's a good question. We look at it periodically. The retail business is materially different from the refining business, and you know that. I mean, we're finance capital intensive and fewer people, and the retail business is people intensive. And when we look at it, I think our view would generally be that we don't need to control the retail outlet to be able to be a very good supplier into that market. And so frankly, what we're focused on is further extending our wholesale business where we could have contractual relationships and support the Valero brand at The Street from the wholesale side rather than from a direct retail operation. If you reflect back on our retail volumes when we owned CST in the thousand or so sites in the sites in Canada, the volume we moved through them was about 125,000 barrels a day. And when you look at that as its order of magnitude relative to the total motor fuels that Valero's producing, it's a very small percentage. So it would take a real huge step for us to have any kind of material presence to really allow us to hedge the benefits associated with owning retail directly. So I don't know that -- unless there was really something that was just incredibly good or allowed us to sustain our contractual relationships with customers, I don't see us reentering that market in the retail business.

componenttext: Yes, Jeff. This is Gary. So Line 9, we began taking crude in December. It's fully up and operational in that capacity. In terms of flexibility of grades, all of our crude 2 Line 9 goes through Montreal, and we really don't have logistics to be taking heavy or medium sours. It's pretty much just for light sweet crude for the Québec refinery.

componenttext: I guess maybe coming back to the gasoline question for this summer, octane availability. As you look around, what do you think the biggest roadblock will be again? Is it going to be the octane alkylate side? Is it going to be blending stocks? And what is your assumption for gasoline demand growth this year as you set up your expectations and budget?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Roger. This is Gary. I think we see that as long as we have a strong gasoline market and we have length in sub-octane blend component like naphtha, the gasoline pull is going to try to draw naphtha in, and it's going to mean octane is fairly expensiv
componenttext: Hey, Roger. This is Gary. I think we see that as long as we have a strong gasoline market and we have length in sub-octane blend component like naphtha, the gasoline pull is going to try to draw naphtha in, and it's going to mean octane is fairly expensive. And so we expect to see alkylate values fairly strong again this summer. And I don't see anything on the horizon that really leads me to believe that's going to change anytime soon.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And where will the industry look? I mean, if you thought about as a low hanging fruit, then where would you be looking to pick up octane? I mean, one of the thoughts is if U.S. light sweet is declining and we're importing a light barrel, maybe we create a
componenttext: And where will the industry look? I mean, if you thought about as a low hanging fruit, then where would you be looking to pick up octane? I mean, one of the thoughts is if U.S. light sweet is declining and we're importing a light barrel, maybe we create a little bit more that way since the U.S. barrels tended to be on the low end for octane. But where else should we consider?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think for us, we try to look everywhere we can. And this alky project was the best thing that we really felt was out there. We've studied reforming, expanding reforming, building new reformers and the alky project has the best return in our system
componenttext: Well, I think for us, we try to look everywhere we can. And this alky project was the best thing that we really felt was out there. We've studied reforming, expanding reforming, building new reformers and the alky project has the best return in our system.

componenttext: Yes, I think we will. I don't see anything in the near term that's going to have a significant impact on the octane balance.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask one more about the alky project tier. There's a couple others out there in the system. A lot of times, these units as nearly those units are paired with like a midstream acquisition or some other project to produce the feed by the operator
componenttext: I wanted to ask one more about the alky project tier. There's a couple others out there in the system. A lot of times, these units as nearly those units are paired with like a midstream acquisition or some other project to produce the feed by the operator. But is it fair to say that there's no real necessity to commit capital to source incremental NGLs here, there's plenty available, and so this alky unit can be built as a stand-alone? Or actually is it -- does it -- is it paired with maybe something coming off the toppers or another attribute of your yield right now?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, Sam. This is Lane. So ours is a little bit different I would say than other people in the industry, and what we're doing is we're taking existing Appalachian unit at Houston and we're converting it to alkylate P5 olefins. And normally, alkylation u
componenttext: Right, Sam. This is Lane. So ours is a little bit different I would say than other people in the industry, and what we're doing is we're taking existing Appalachian unit at Houston and we're converting it to alkylate P5 olefins. And normally, alkylation units alkylate P4 olefins and sometimes P3 olefins. So we're taking the existing ones, retrofit it such that it could alkylate P5 olefins. And we're building a new C4 olefins. What we're really doing if you draw a neuro boundary around the Houston refinery is we're shifting C5 olefins that were going out in cat gasoline, bringing in IC4 from Mont Bellevue, which is readily available and inexpensive. And that's really what's happening in making an alkylate and also blending some additional butane for the full RVP. That's really what this project is. So it is different than, I would say, other people that are looking at this. And we're clearly ahead of everybody else in the industry with this projects.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yes, that makes sense. I think it's been evaluated for quite a while. So it's clear that there's a lot of, I guess, thought into the process. This next one's sort of a moon shot. I think as you know it's been reported, Aramco is may be's looking to
componenttext: Okay. Yes, that makes sense. I think it's been evaluated for quite a while. So it's clear that there's a lot of, I guess, thought into the process. This next one's sort of a moon shot. I think as you know it's been reported, Aramco is may be's looking to monetize some assets. You might also know that Shell has a fairly aggressive divestment target, too. I don't know. Is it fair to say that Motiva today is at least as attractive or as sensible of a consolidation candidate as maybe CITGO was 2 years ago in terms of sort of what's out there to bring into the fold to the extent that, I think Mike kind of alluded to, the appetite hasn't changed, but I don't know, maybe availability of assets has?

componenttext: Well, Sam, that is a moonshot. I mean, Motiva has a good business, and they've got good assets. And if they were for sale, I suspect that we'd take a really good hard look at. But we're not hearing anything, I haven't heard anything that they're in the market.

componenttext: Well, there's quite a bit of uncertainty in the market. And so at this point in time, I really can't comment on how the cash proceeds would be and if it could be structured.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe one follow-up on -- we appreciate the comments you made earlier in terms of some your thoughts on medium sour and heavy sour differentials and the sustainability going forward. But maybe can you -- any -- can you give any thoughts in
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe one follow-up on -- we appreciate the comments you made earlier in terms of some your thoughts on medium sour and heavy sour differentials and the sustainability going forward. But maybe can you -- any -- can you give any thoughts in terms of how you see light sweet depths, whether it's Brent TI or LLSTI evolving over the next 3 to 6 months? Are we going to need to see a widening of those spreads in order to clear cushion in this incentivized imports? And in particular, I was kind of curious given the fact that you backed out 400,000 barrels a day of Lower 48 light sweet crude to your system, just generally how you've seen -- what your outlook is for those light sweet differentials going forward over the next -- over the course of this year.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Gary. I think over time, LLS and Brent trade is pretty close to parity. But I think we're going to have a lot of volatility between the grades as the year goes on. So you can see LLS got -- as was paying -- we would have to pay premium for LL
componenttext: Yes, this is Gary. I think over time, LLS and Brent trade is pretty close to parity. But I think we're going to have a lot of volatility between the grades as the year goes on. So you can see LLS got -- as was paying -- we would have to pay premium for LLS over Brent. So we started importing foreign light sweet. You have inventory gains here in the U.S., which I think tells you LLS was too expensive. So then LLS will be discounted. And I think we'll go through that volatility for the next 6 months where we swing in and out of domestic light sweet production into our refining system.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Joe, I wanted to back to your comment about gasoline, on -- I think you said you were at max gasoline mode right now. What I'm trying to understand is what happens to gasoline yields as the U.S. kind of swings back to imports on light sweet crude decli
componenttext: So Joe, I wanted to back to your comment about gasoline, on -- I think you said you were at max gasoline mode right now. What I'm trying to understand is what happens to gasoline yields as the U.S. kind of swings back to imports on light sweet crude decline. So I know everyone's focused on octane, but I'm just wondering if we start to see a tightening of the balance to the [indiscernible] gasoline more at this point. I'm guessing that's because distillates are weak. I'm just trying to understand the interplay as you see things going into the summer. So I guess, I'm really looking to your progress on how those things balance out.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Gary, you want to go ahead?
componenttext: Okay. Gary, you want to go ahead?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so overall, if you look at foreign light sweet barrel versus an Eagle Ford or Bakken type barrel, the naphtha yield from West African Saharan barrel is about the same as Bakken or Eagle Ford. So in terms of refining yield, it's not significantly diff
componenttext: Yes, so overall, if you look at foreign light sweet barrel versus an Eagle Ford or Bakken type barrel, the naphtha yield from West African Saharan barrel is about the same as Bakken or Eagle Ford. So in terms of refining yield, it's not significantly different whether we're running that West African barrel or we're running a domestic light sweet barrel.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But as you swing back towards medium heavy, does the yield mix change then?
componenttext: But as you swing back towards medium heavy, does the yield mix change then?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So for medium to heavy barrel, it would, except for most of the refiners we're running, those barrels are very high complexity refining assets. And again, we don't see much of a yield difference with the complexity of our refineries when we're runnin
componenttext: Yes. So for medium to heavy barrel, it would, except for most of the refiners we're running, those barrels are very high complexity refining assets. And again, we don't see much of a yield difference with the complexity of our refineries when we're running a heavier diet. The only thing that we can get into is as we go heavy in some of our plants, it can lower utilization some. So we get a lever effect by running light sweet in some of our refineries. So we have a big incentive to run much heavier crude diet. It can mean that we're running slightly lower crude rate in some of those plants.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Can't abide to the old school, I guess. My follow-up surely more a -- is probably more a Ciskowski question then. Mike, the tax rate looks like it's been consistently low now for -- it's becoming a kind of a regular thing. So should we be looking at tax r
componenttext: Can't abide to the old school, I guess. My follow-up surely more a -- is probably more a Ciskowski question then. Mike, the tax rate looks like it's been consistently low now for -- it's becoming a kind of a regular thing. So should we be looking at tax rate guidance moving lower as a kind of permanent shift?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we have a couple of unique items this past quarter because of the tax law finally was -- they got final approval in the U.K. and then we had -- we have some audits that are underway in the U.S. And we happen to get those settled this quarter. And so
componenttext: Well, we have a couple of unique items this past quarter because of the tax law finally was -- they got final approval in the U.K. and then we had -- we have some audits that are underway in the U.S. And we happen to get those settled this quarter. And so that was reflective, which pushed the break down to 28%. So we try to do the best the we can and given that guidance to you. But I -- the 31%, 32% is what I would say for the first quarter.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that a good run rate going forward, Mike?
componenttext: Is that a good run rate going forward, Mike?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Right now, that would be.
componenttext: Yes. Right now, that would be.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor, Pickering and Holt.
componenttext: Our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor, Pickering and Holt.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back on the products markets. Can you comment on how you're assessing the supply-demand balance of the global distillate market heading into this year? We saw material weakening of the diesel cracks as the year progressed last year and just wondering on y
componenttext: Back on the products markets. Can you comment on how you're assessing the supply-demand balance of the global distillate market heading into this year? We saw material weakening of the diesel cracks as the year progressed last year and just wondering on your thoughts on the cause of this.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chi, this is Gary Simmons. Overall, I think if you look at what drive distillate demand, it's weather and then it's economic activity. And thus far, both in the U.S. and in Northwest Europe, we've had warmer winters than what we've historically had.
componenttext: Yes, Chi, this is Gary Simmons. Overall, I think if you look at what drive distillate demand, it's weather and then it's economic activity. And thus far, both in the U.S. and in Northwest Europe, we've had warmer winters than what we've historically had. And so it's led to lower distillate demand. So in terms of how do we correct from here, I think a lot of that correction gets back to some of this low complexity refining capacity with discounted fuel pricing, I think we'll see some economic run cuts. Some of that low complexity capacity that will bring the distillate market back into balance.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What about the economic activity side of things? I mean, are you seeing -- you mentioned your exports are still pretty good, but are you concerned about global slowdown on the economic front?
componenttext: What about the economic activity side of things? I mean, are you seeing -- you mentioned your exports are still pretty good, but are you concerned about global slowdown on the economic front?

componenttext: This is Lane. So McKee be -- we finished that project, which really took us about 2 years to fully implement the entire scope of that which was 2 things: one was, there was an energy efficiency project and distillate recovery; and the second was sort of plus crude rate. And we finished it in October. And I assume that's what you're after, you're sort of after the time... okay. And [indiscernible] again, the hydrocracker was down in October and then we replaced the catalyst and did the expansion. And then Corpus Christi really started up gearing sort of early to mid-December. So you wouldn't have seen anything with respect to fourth quarter improvement. That's really going to be entirely a 2016 thing.

componenttext: This is Martin Parrish. Well, it's really the impact on the blending margin, not on the refinery's margin. componenttext: Circling back to VLP. I'm just curious, we all know the uncertainty and the turmoil in the capital markets, but it seems like the strategy is basically unchanged, and you have 55% of the growth in 2016 in terms of budget going in the VLP. At what point do you think about that and maybe re-examine the pace of growth, given that the market doesn't necessarily seem to be rewarding growth as much as it once was?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we'll continue to -- that's our -- right now, our plan is to do the $1 billion, but we'll continue to examine and monitor the markets as we move through the year. I mean, it is very challenging right now. We do have our revolver that we could
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we'll continue to -- that's our -- right now, our plan is to do the $1 billion, but we'll continue to examine and monitor the markets as we move through the year. I mean, it is very challenging right now. We do have our revolver that we could use that as a financing source for some of the drops. So the bank market seems to be a little bit more attractive than the capital markets at this point in time.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, let me just add to what Mike said, though. The capital that we're investing in logistics assets at Valero Energy are assets that can be dropped to VLP. So we'll continue to build the droppable EBITDA base. But the motivation behind it, and we've sha
componenttext: Brad, let me just add to what Mike said, though. The capital that we're investing in logistics assets at Valero Energy are assets that can be dropped to VLP. So we'll continue to build the droppable EBITDA base. But the motivation behind it, and we've shared this before, the motivation behind Valero investing in logistics assets are projects that benefit Valero's core business, its core refining business. They're projects that help us optimize our operations. And we're not taking flyers on projects that we wouldn't be willing to commit contractually long term to. And so again, the things we're investing in today, for example, the Diamond Pipeline. I mean, that is going to be a direct benefit to the Memphis refinery and provide crude optionality there that they don't currently have today. So this is a -- it's a long game and even though markets are challenged right now, I don't think we should sit here and throw the baby out with the bath water and totally redirect strategies to try to accommodate it. The other thing that Mike has mentioned is that VLP is in a great position. They got very high coverage ratios to maintain distribution growth at the targets we've talked about, is not going to be an issue. And here again, we're running the business to continue to improve the business and drive EPS growth at VLO, and VLP is going to go along for the ride. So anyway, that's just a little more color.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I don't suspect it's a lot of refiners building inventory. Most of our tankage and most refiners' tankage is more operational in nature, and so it's hard to really utilize that tankage for a Contango place. So most of that, you see some inventory bui
componenttext: Yes. I don't suspect it's a lot of refiners building inventory. Most of our tankage and most refiners' tankage is more operational in nature, and so it's hard to really utilize that tankage for a Contango place. So most of that, you see some inventory building cushion, but I don't know that I really could comment in terms of the build. I think we had happen is LLS got in the premium to a foreign light sweet alternative and Valero, along with many other refiners, started buying light sweet and caused the inventory to build and certainly, the market structures incentivized people to store as well.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Yolanda, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.It's now my pleasur
componenttext:
Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2015 Fourth Quarter Earnings Conference Call. My name is Yolanda, and I'll be your operator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded.
It's now my pleasure to turn the call over to Mr. John Locke. You may begin.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's Fourth Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our Executive Vice President of Refining Operations and Engineering; Jay Browning, our Executive Vice President and General Counsel; and several other members of Valero's senior management team. If you have not received the earnings release and would like a copy, you can find one on our website at valero.com. Also attached to the earnings release are tables that provide additional financial information on our business segments. If you have any questions after reviewing these tables, please feel free to contact our Investor Relations team after the call.
I would like to direct your attention to the forward-looking statement disclaimer contained in the press release. In summary, it says that statements in the press release and on this conference call that state the company's or management's expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions under federal securities laws. There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations, including those we've described in our filings with the SEC.
Now I will turn the call over to Joe for a few opening remarks.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone.The fourth quarter and full year 2015 were really great for Valero. We operated safely and reliably, achieving our lowest ever employee injury rate in refining and reaching an annual average refinery utiliz
componenttext:
Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone.
The fourth quarter and full year 2015 were really great for Valero. We operated safely and reliably, achieving our lowest ever employee injury rate in refining and reaching an annual average refinery utilization rate of 95%. The markets were favorable during the quarter. Domestic product demand grew supported by lower pump prices and sour crude discounts relative to the Brent were attractive to our highly complex refining system. While distillate margins were pressured during unseasonably warm weather in North America and Europe, distillate demand in Latin America remained robust. In fact, we exported record volumes of distillate and gasoline in the fourth quarter.
We continue to execute well on our projects. In the quarter we successfully commissioned the new Corpus Christi crude unit, the Port Arthur gas-oil hydrocracker expansion and the McKee crude unit expansion. Our Québec City refinery also began receiving crude via Enbridge's Line 9B. We exercised our option with Plains All American to acquire a 50% interest in the Diamond crude oil pipeline project. Once completed, this project will connect Cushing with Memphis and provide us with crude optionality and long-term cost savings versus sourcing crude oil from St. James. 
Additionally, Valero Energy Partners continues to execute its growth strategy, and Valero GP's interest in VLP reached the high splits with the distribution increase we announced earlier this week.
We also continue to advance our refining growth strategy. Construction of the Houston crude unit remains on schedule with startup planned in the second quarter of 2016. And earlier this month our Board of Directors approved the Houston alkylation project. This project is estimated to cost $300 million and is expected to be completed in the first half of 2019.
And finally, regarding cash returns to stockholders, we paid out 80% of our 2015 adjusted net income, exceeding the 75% annual payout target. Further demonstrating our belief in Valero's earnings potential, last week our Board of Directors approved a 20% increase in the regular quarterly dividend to $0.60 per share or $2.40 annually.
With that, John, I'll hand it back over to you.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Thank you, Joe.Moving on to the results. We reported fourth quarter 2015 adjusted net income from continuing operations of $862 million or $1.79 per share versus $952 million or $1.83 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014. Actual net income fro
componenttext:
Okay. Thank you, Joe.
Moving on to the results. We reported fourth quarter 2015 adjusted net income from continuing operations of $862 million or $1.79 per share versus $952 million or $1.83 per share for the fourth quarter of 2014. Actual net income from continuing operations was $298 million or $0.62 per share, which compares to $1.2 billion or $2.22 per share in the fourth quarter of 2014. Please refer to the reconciliations of actual to adjusted amounts as shown in the financial tables that accompany our release.
For 2015, we reported adjusted net income from continuing operations of $4.6 billion or $9.24 per share compared to $3.5 billion or $6.68 per share for 2014. Actual net income from continuing operations was $4 billion or $7.99 per share in 2015 versus $3.7 billion or $6.97 per share in 2014. 
Fourth quarter 2015 refining segment adjusted operating income of $1.5 billion was in line with the fourth quarter of 2014. Stronger gasoline and other product margins combined with higher refining throughput volumes were offset by lower distillate and petrochemical margins and lower discounts for sweet crude oils relative to Brent crude oil.
Refining throughput volumes averaged 2.9 million barrels per day, which was 34,000 barrels per day higher than the fourth quarter of 2014. Our refineries operated at 97% throughput capacity utilization in the fourth quarter of 2015. Refining cash operating expenses of $3.47 per barrel or $0.29 per barrel lower than the fourth quarter of 2014, largely driven by favorable property tax settlements and reserve adjustments and lower energy cost.
The ethanol segment generated $37 million of adjusted operating income in the fourth quarter of 2015 versus $154 million in the fourth quarter of 2014, due primarily to lower gross margin per gallon driven by a decline in ethanol prices versus relatively stable corn prices. 
For the fourth quarter of 2015, general and administrative expenses excluding corporate depreciation were $206 million, and net interest expense was $107 million. Depreciation and amortization expense was $494 million, and the effective tax rate was 28% in the fourth quarter of 2015. The effective tax rate was lower than expected due primarily to a reduction in the statutory tax rate in the United Kingdom and the settlement of income tax audits in the United States.
With respect to our balance sheet at quarter end, total debt was $7.4 billion, and cash and temporary cash investments were $4.1 billion, of which $81 million was held by VLP. Valero's debt to capitalization ratio, net of $2 billion in cash, was 20%. We have $5.6 billion of available liquidity, excluding cash. Cash flows in the fourth quarter included $732 million of capital investments, of which $164 million was for turnaround and catalyst, and $136 million was for investment in the Diamond pipeline.
For 2015, capital investment included $1.4 billion for stay-in-business and $1 billion for growth. We returned $1 billion in cash to our stockholders in the fourth quarter, which included $240 million in dividend payments and $767 million for the purchase of 11.1 million shares of Valero common stock. For 2015, we purchased 44.9 million shares for $2.8 billion.
For 2016, we maintain our guidance of $2.6 billion for capital investments, including turnarounds, catalyst, joint venture and strategic investments. This consists of approximately $1.6 billion for stay-in-business and $1 billion for growth. For modeling our first quarter operations, we expect throughput volumes to fall within the following ranges: U.S. Gulf Coast at 1.61 million to 1.66 million barrels per day; U.S. Mid-Continent at 430,000 to 450,000 barrels per day; U.S. West Coast at 245,000 to 265,000 barrels per day; and North Atlantic at 465,000 to 485,000 barrels per day. We expect refining cash operating expenses in the first quarter to be approximately $3.85 per barrel.
Our ethanol segment is expected to produce a total of 3.8 million gallons per day in the first quarter. Operating expenses should average $0.37 per gallon, which includes $0.05 per gallon for noncash costs such as depreciation and amortization. We expect G&A expenses, excluding corporate depreciation for the first quarter, to be around $175 million, and net interest expense should be about $110 million. Total depreciation and amortization expense should be approximately $470 million, and our effective tax rate is expected to be around 32%.
That concludes our opening remarks. [Operator Instructions]
