Just a quick question on the alkylation unit. First, can you provide any kind of return expectations that you have for the project? 
And then secondly, on the spending profile, it looks like your CapEx guidance into '16 is about the same as it was before. So I'm just kind of confirming that most of the spending probably is weighted towards '17 and '18?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, the -- hey, Blake, this is Lane. Yes, the Board approved the alkylation unit. It was nominally about $300 million. The [indiscernible] decision EBITDA is about $105 million. If you use 2015 prices, it would be about $140 million EBITDA. With respect
componenttext: Well, the -- hey, Blake, this is Lane. Yes, the Board approved the alkylation unit. It was nominally about $300 million. The [indiscernible] decision EBITDA is about $105 million. If you use 2015 prices, it would be about $140 million EBITDA. With respect to the budget, we -- when you look at our original -- we gave out the 2016 guidance on our budget for this year two years ago. It's up about $100 million, and it's nominally the Port Arthur turnaround. We had a little more turnaround than we -- than our outlook was two years ago. But certainly -- and then all the rest of it, alky is clearly fitting inside our sort of $100 billion a year strategic capital. It's not -- well, it's nominally about $100 million a year, and it is in fact weighted, like you said, towards 2017 and 2018.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Secondly, just maybe if you don't mind sharing some thoughts around light-heavy spreads into '16, and I guess what I'm thinking, especially in light of Iranian barrels coming to market, that could potentially displace other barrels globally. seems like ma
componenttext: Secondly, just maybe if you don't mind sharing some thoughts around light-heavy spreads into '16, and I guess what I'm thinking, especially in light of Iranian barrels coming to market, that could potentially displace other barrels globally. seems like maybe that would have an indirect benefit to Valero, given your leverage to Gulf Coast and heavy processing.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Blake, this is Gary Simmons. Overall, yes, we've seen very good spreads between the medium sours and light and heavy sours as well. And certainly the Iranian production coming online will put further pressure on those differentials. I think we see se
componenttext:
Yes, Blake, this is Gary Simmons. Overall, yes, we've seen very good spreads between the medium sours and light and heavy sours as well. And certainly the Iranian production coming online will put further pressure on those differentials. I think we see several things in the market. As you know, the increase in OPEC productions put medium sour barrels into the Gulf. You see Gulf of Mexico deepwater medium sour production rising. At the same time we're seeing some of the light sweet production falling off here in the United States, leading to very good differentials. 
I think the other thing that's a fundamental shift is, where fuel had been trading around 80% of Brent, it's now trading around 60% of Brent, which should mean that we would expect to see good medium sour and heavy sour differentials throughout the year. I think the other thing for us, the Iranian production, of course we won't be running any of those barrels, but we do think the market rebalances and makes some additional heavy and medium grades available from us -- to us from Latin America.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our next question comes from Neil Mehta from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Joe, Lane and Gary, you guys have a unique window into what's happening from a product demand perspective. It's one of the big debates in the oil markets right now. Can you talk about what the export markets look like from your perspective for diesel a
componenttext: So Joe, Lane and Gary, you guys have a unique window into what's happening from a product demand perspective. It's one of the big debates in the oil markets right now. Can you talk about what the export markets look like from your perspective for diesel and gasoline? And then to piggyback off of that, you've seen four weeks now of these gasoline builds in the DOEs. Is that consistent with what you're seeing on the ground?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Neil, this is Gary. I think we continue to see very good export demand for our product. As Joe mentioned, we had record volumes in the fourth quarter. We continue to see good demand for both distillate and gasoline abroad. Our rack volumes remain ver
componenttext:
Yes, Neil, this is Gary. I think we continue to see very good export demand for our product. As Joe mentioned, we had record volumes in the fourth quarter. We continue to see good demand for both distillate and gasoline abroad. Our rack volumes remain very strong. We're moving a lot of product over the racks. We've seen good domestic demand for our product as well. 
Certainly I think when you get this early in the year it's kind of hard to dissect the DOE data. We've seen the large builds as well. Some of the data does looks a little suspect. I think we've seen a lot of weather issues in the Gulf that our belief may have been that it hindered some of the waterborne barrels from being able to leave due to fog and weather that we've had in the Gulf. And the Mississippi River flooding also has hindered some of the refineries along the rivers, the ability to clear those barrels as well. I think we're just too early to really get a good view of what demand's going to look like, but everything from us, our perspective looks good.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, the fundamentals, I think, for strong demand are still there. There's no question about that. I mean, we continue to have prices that are very attractive at the street. And then there's a lot of data that's coming out recently on vehicle miles travel
componenttext: Yes, the fundamentals, I think, for strong demand are still there. There's no question about that. I mean, we continue to have prices that are very attractive at the street. And then there's a lot of data that's coming out recently on vehicle miles traveled being up and also on auto sales being skewed towards larger SUVs and light heavy trucks. So again, as Gary said, it seems like every January, Neil, we find ourselves in a situation where we're looking at the year, and everybody's trying to figure out, oh, gee, it's over and is demand going to be totally eroded. And as he said, I think it's just a little early to tell. But fundamentally, it looks like things should go well for us going forward.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. Thanks, Joe. I appreciate it. For Valero, our appetite for midstream M&A and M&A in general hasn't changed. We continue to look at opportunities, particularly those that support the earnings growth that we continue to achieve in our core business. Th
componenttext:
Yes. Thanks, Joe. I appreciate it. For Valero, our appetite for midstream M&A and M&A in general hasn't changed. We continue to look at opportunities, particularly those that support the earnings growth that we continue to achieve in our core business. The good news is we have a great portfolio of significant earnings capability, as we demonstrated in '15. 
More specific to VLP, VLP hasn't reached the size where it can execute most of the M&A transactions on its own. But we do continue to evaluate opportunities there as well. But as we said before, we remain committed to VLP's drop-down growth strategy, and we're not interested in a step-out transaction that would change VLP's risk profile or its growth story.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Mike, actually this is for you. I'm going to ask from the other angle on the balance sheet. The last several years that you guys have done phenomenally well, both operationally and financially, and also there was return to shareholder. I'm just curious, t
componenttext:
Mike, actually this is for you. I'm going to ask from the other angle on the balance sheet. The last several years that you guys have done phenomenally well, both operationally and financially, and also there was return to shareholder. I'm just curious, then, has the cash flow remained strong at this point? Does it make sense, even though you already have a very, very strong balance sheet, to maybe utilize part of the free cash flow, maybe 20% or so, to further strengthen the balance sheet? 
I think that we all live through the up and down. While I'm bullish on the market, I could be wrong. And that we have seen what happened to everyone was bullish in 2007 and then the bottom fell off because of the economy. So should we actually take maybe a slightly different view at this point just as a safe thought to ensure that we build up some additional cushion, even though your balance sheet is already remarkably strong? But if cash flow cut by half, then maybe that will allow you to even have better opportunity to strike and take the opportunity everyone that's weak.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's quite a question, Paul. Yes, I remember those days very well. Our balance sheet is very strong, and we intend to keep it that way. If you're suggesting that we take -- that we build cash here, our current focus is to continue to look for oppo
componenttext: Okay. That's quite a question, Paul. Yes, I remember those days very well. Our balance sheet is very strong, and we intend to keep it that way. If you're suggesting that we take -- that we build cash here, our current focus is to continue to look for opportunity to grow our business and increase our earnings per share. But if you're suggesting that we prepay some debt, the majority of our remaining debt contains make-whole provisions that make those prepayments less than compelling.

componenttext: And then, Joe, just curious that with -- I think that some of the other company in distress and look like some retail [indiscernible] maybe become cheaper. If you're looking at your portfolio, does it make sense that, if the entry point is right for you to reenter into retail, by doing so that can, maybe that cushion you against or hedge against any real cost increase or that [indiscernible] more outlet, direct outlet to your own refine product? Or that this is [indiscernible] by going back into that business?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Now, Paul, that's a good question. We look at it periodically. The retail business is materially different from the refining business, and you know that. I mean, we're -- refine is capital intensive and fewer people and the retail business is people inten
componenttext:
Now, Paul, that's a good question. We look at it periodically. The retail business is materially different from the refining business, and you know that. I mean, we're -- refine is capital intensive and fewer people and the retail business is people intensive. And when we look at it, I think our view would generally be that we don't need to control the retail outlet to be able to be a very good supplier into that market. And so frankly, what we're focused on is further extending our wholesale business where we could have contractual relationships and support the Valero brand at the street from the wholesale side rather than from a direct retail operation. 
If you reflect back on our retail volumes when we owned CST in the thousand or so sites, in the sites in Canada, the volume we moved through them was about 125,000 barrels a day. And when you look at that as its order of magnitude relative to the total motor fuels that Valero's producing, it's a very small percentage. So it would take a real huge step for us to have any kind of material presence to really allow us to hedge the benefits associated with owning retail directly. So I don't know that -- unless there was really something that was just incredibly good or allowed us to sustain our contractual relationships with customers, I don't see us reentering that market in the retail business.

componenttext: Yes, Jeff. This is Gary. So Line 9, we began taking crude in December. It's fully up and operational and at capacity. In terms of flexibility of grades, all of our crude through Line 9 goes through Montreal, and we really don't have logistics to be taking heavy or medium sours. It's pretty much just for light sweet crude for the Québec refinery.

componenttext: I guess maybe coming back to the gasoline question for this summer, octane availability. As you look around, what do you think the biggest roadblock will be again? Is it going to be the octane alkylate side? Is it going to be blending stocks? And what is your assumption for gasoline demand growth this year as you set up your expectations and budget?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hey, Roger. This is Gary. I think we see that, as long as we have a strong gasoline market and we have length in sub-octane blend component like naphtha, the gasoline pool is going to try to draw naphtha in, and it's going to mean octane is fairly expensi
componenttext: Hey, Roger. This is Gary. I think we see that, as long as we have a strong gasoline market and we have length in sub-octane blend component like naphtha, the gasoline pool is going to try to draw naphtha in, and it's going to mean octane is fairly expensive. And so we expect to see alkylate values fairly strong again this summer. And I don't see anything on the horizon that really leads me to believe that's going to change anytime soon.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And where will the industry look? I mean, if you thought about it as a low hanging fruit, then, where would you be looking to pick up octane? I mean, one of the thoughts is if U.S. light sweet is declining and we're importing a light barrel, maybe we crea
componenttext: And where will the industry look? I mean, if you thought about it as a low hanging fruit, then, where would you be looking to pick up octane? I mean, one of the thoughts is if U.S. light sweet is declining and we're importing a light barrel, maybe we create a little bit more that way since the U.S. barrels tended to be on the low end for octane. But where else should we consider?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I think for us, we try to look everywhere we can. And this alky project was the best thing that we really felt was out there. We've studied reforming, expanding reforming, building new reformers, and the alky project had the best return in our syste
componenttext: Well, I think for us, we try to look everywhere we can. And this alky project was the best thing that we really felt was out there. We've studied reforming, expanding reforming, building new reformers, and the alky project had the best return in our system.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask one more about the alky project here. There's a couple others out there in the system. A lot of times these units, newly built units are paired with like a midstream acquisition or some other project to produce the feed by the operator. Bu
componenttext: I wanted to ask one more about the alky project here. There's a couple others out there in the system. A lot of times these units, newly built units are paired with like a midstream acquisition or some other project to produce the feed by the operator. But is it fair to say that there's no real necessity to commit capital to source incremental NGLs here, there's plenty available, and so this alky unit can be built as a stand-alone? Or actually is it -- does it -- is it paired with maybe something coming off the toppers or another attribute of your yield right now?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Right, Sam. This is Lane. So ours is a little bit different, I would say, than other people in the industry, and what we're doing is we're taking an existing alkylation unit at Houston and we're converting it to alkylate P5 olefins. Normally alkylation un
componenttext: Right, Sam. This is Lane. So ours is a little bit different, I would say, than other people in the industry, and what we're doing is we're taking an existing alkylation unit at Houston and we're converting it to alkylate P5 olefins. Normally alkylation units alkylate P4 olefins and sometimes P3 olefins. So we're taking the existing ones, retrofit it such that it could alkylate P5 olefins, and we're building these new C4 olefins. What we're really doing, if you drew a boundary around the Houston refinery, is we're shifting C5 olefins that were going out in cat [ph] gasoline, bringing in IC4 from Mont Belvieu, which is readily available and inexpensive. And that's really what's happening in making an alkylate and also blending some additional butane for the full RVP. That's really what this project is. So it is different than, I would say, other people that are looking at this. And we're clearly ahead of everybody else in the industry with this project.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext:
Okay. Yes, that makes sense. I think it's been evaluated for quite a while. So it's clear that there's a lot of, I guess, thought into the process. 
This next one's sort of a moonshot. I think, as you know, it's been reported Aramco is maybe looking to monetize some assets. You might also know that Shell has a fairly aggressive divestment target, too. I don't know, is it fair to say that Motiva today is at least as attractive or as sensible of a consolidation candidate as maybe CITGO was 2 years ago in terms of sort of what's out there to bring into the fold to the extent that, I think Mike kind of alluded to, the appetite hasn't changed, but I don't know, maybe availability of assets has?

componenttext: Well, Sam, that is a moonshot. I mean, Motiva has a good business, and they've got good assets. And if they were for sale, I suspect that we'd take a really good hard look at it. But we're not hearing anything. I haven't heard anything that they're in the market.

componenttext: Okay. Yes, Phil, right now our -- $1 billion is our current plan for the drop-down. But the capital markets are pretty challenging right now. So we'll just have to continue to monitor this as we move through the year.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Second question is just there's been some talk about the uplift we could see from greater utilization rates from these Chinese teapot refineries and the impact they could have on product exports out of China. I'm just wondering how you're thinking a
componenttext: Okay. Second question is just there's been some talk about the uplift we could see from greater utilization rates from these Chinese teapot refineries and the impact they could have on product exports out of China. I'm just wondering how you're thinking about this risk? And do you think China's product quality can compete on the global market, especially on the gasoline side?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I can't -- Phil, this is Gary. I don't know that I could really comment on the quality of their products. Overall, to me, that capacity is capacity that's going to be very challenged globally because of the weak fuel oil markets. It's going to be very dif
componenttext: I can't -- Phil, this is Gary. I don't know that I could really comment on the quality of their products. Overall, to me, that capacity is capacity that's going to be very challenged globally because of the weak fuel oil markets. It's going to be very difficult to run low budgeting capacity with a very low fuel oil environment.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Ryan Todd from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Maybe you've said all you wanted to say on it, but maybe a quick follow-up on the prior question on potential drops to VLP. I mean, any thoughts as to what the mix might look like between cash proceeds and equity to Valero? Or any thoughts on evolution of multiples of those drops? Or too much uncertainty in the market at this point?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Well, there's quite a bit of uncertainty in the market. And so at this point in time I really can't comment on how the cash proceeds would be and [indiscernible] would be structured.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then maybe one follow-up on -- we appreciate the comments you made earlier in terms of some of your thoughts on medium sour and heavy sour differentials and the sustainability going forward. But maybe can you -- any -- can you give any thoughts
componenttext: Okay. And then maybe one follow-up on -- we appreciate the comments you made earlier in terms of some of your thoughts on medium sour and heavy sour differentials and the sustainability going forward. But maybe can you -- any -- can you give any thoughts in terms of how you see light sweet diffs, whether it's Brent TI or LLSTI, evolving over the next 3 to 6 months? Are we going to need to see a widening of those spreads in order to clear cushion in this incentivized imports? And in particular, I was kind of curious, given the fact that you backed out 400,000 barrels a day of Lower 48 light sweet crude to your system, just generally how you've seen -- what your outlook is for those light sweet differentials going forward over the next -- over the course of this year.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, this is Gary. I think over time LLS and Brent trade at pretty close to parity. But I think we're going to have a lot of volatility between the grades as the year goes on. So you can see LLS got -- it was paying -- we would have to pay premium for LLS
componenttext: Yes, this is Gary. I think over time LLS and Brent trade at pretty close to parity. But I think we're going to have a lot of volatility between the grades as the year goes on. So you can see LLS got -- it was paying -- we would have to pay premium for LLS over Brent so we started importing foreign light sweet. You have inventory gains here in the U.S., which I think tells you LLS was too expensive, so then LLS will be discounted. And I think we'll go through that volatility for the next 6 months, where we swing in and out of domestic light sweet production into our refining system.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Doug Leggate from Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So Joe, I wanted to go back to your comment about gasoline on -- I think you said you were in max gasoline mode right now. What I'm trying to understand is what happens to gasoline yields as the U.S. kind of swings back to imports and light sweet crude de
componenttext: So Joe, I wanted to go back to your comment about gasoline on -- I think you said you were in max gasoline mode right now. What I'm trying to understand is what happens to gasoline yields as the U.S. kind of swings back to imports and light sweet crude declines. So I know everyone's focused on octane, but I'm just wondering, if we start to see a tightening of the balance to the [indiscernible] gasoline more at this point. I'm guessing that's because distillates are so weak. I'm just trying to understand the interplay as you see things going into the summer. So I guess I'm really looking to your prognosis on how those things balance out.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Gary, you want to go ahead?
componenttext: Okay. Gary, you want to go ahead?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so overall, if you look at a foreign light sweet barrel versus an Eagle Ford or a Bakken type barrel, the naphtha yield from West African Saharan barrel is about the same as Bakken or Eagle Ford. So in terms of refining yield, it's not significantly
componenttext: Yes, so overall, if you look at a foreign light sweet barrel versus an Eagle Ford or a Bakken type barrel, the naphtha yield from West African Saharan barrel is about the same as Bakken or Eagle Ford. So in terms of refining yield, it's not significantly different whether we're running that West African barrel or we're running a domestic light sweet barrel.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: But as you swing back towards medium heavy, does the yield mix change, then?
componenttext: But as you swing back towards medium heavy, does the yield mix change, then?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. So for medium to heavy barrel it would, except for most of the refiners were running those barrels at very high complexity refining assets. And again, we don't see much of a yield difference with the complexity of our refineries when we're running a
componenttext: Yes. So for medium to heavy barrel it would, except for most of the refiners were running those barrels at very high complexity refining assets. And again, we don't see much of a yield difference with the complexity of our refineries when we're running a heavier diet. The only thing that we can get into is, as we go heavy in some of our plants, it can lower our utilization some. So we get a lever effect by running light sweet in some of our refineries. So if we have a big incentive to run a much heavier crude diet it can mean that we're running slightly lower crude rate in some of those plants.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Kind of back to the old school, I guess. My follow-up surely more -- is probably more a Ciskowski question, then. Mike, the tax rate looks like it's been consistently low now for -- it's becoming kind of a regular thing. So should we be looking at tax rat
componenttext: Kind of back to the old school, I guess. My follow-up surely more -- is probably more a Ciskowski question, then. Mike, the tax rate looks like it's been consistently low now for -- it's becoming kind of a regular thing. So should we be looking at tax rate guidance moving lower as a kind of permanent shift?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, we had a couple of unique items this past quarter because the tax law finally was -- they got final approval in the U.K. and then we had -- we had some audits that are underway in the U.S., and we happened to get those settled this quarter. And so t
componenttext: Well, we had a couple of unique items this past quarter because the tax law finally was -- they got final approval in the U.K. and then we had -- we had some audits that are underway in the U.S., and we happened to get those settled this quarter. And so that was reflective, which pushed the rate down to 28%. So we try to do the best that we can in giving that guidance to you. But I -- 31%, 32% is what I would say for the first quarter.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Is that a good run rate going forward, Mike?
componenttext: Is that a good run rate going forward, Mike?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Yes, right now that would be.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Chi Chow from Tudor, Pickering and Holt.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Back on the products markets. Can you comment on how you're assessing the supply-demand balance of the global distillate market heading into this year? We saw material weakening of the diesel cracks as the year progressed last year and just wondering on y
componenttext: Back on the products markets. Can you comment on how you're assessing the supply-demand balance of the global distillate market heading into this year? We saw material weakening of the diesel cracks as the year progressed last year and just wondering on your thoughts on the cause of this.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Chi, this is Gary Simmons. Overall, I think if you look at what drives distillate demand, it's weather and then it's economic activity. And thus far, both in the U.S. and in Northwest Europe, we've had warmer winters than what we've historically had,
componenttext: Yes, Chi, this is Gary Simmons. Overall, I think if you look at what drives distillate demand, it's weather and then it's economic activity. And thus far, both in the U.S. and in Northwest Europe, we've had warmer winters than what we've historically had, and so it's led to lower distillate demand. So in terms of how do we correct from here, I think a lot of that correction gets back to some of this low complexity refining capacity. With discounted fuel oil pricing I think we'll see some economic run cuts, some of that low complexity capacity that will bring the distillate market back into balance.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What about the economic activity side of things? I mean, are you seeing -- you mentioned your exports are still pretty good, but are you concerned about global slowdown on the economic front?
componenttext: What about the economic activity side of things? I mean, are you seeing -- you mentioned your exports are still pretty good, but are you concerned about global slowdown on the economic front?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I can really comment on the global economic activity, but I can say we continue to see very robust demand for our products throughout the globe.
componenttext: I don't know that I can really comment on the global economic activity, but I can say we continue to see very robust demand for our products throughout the globe.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: What were your exports of gasoline and diesel in the quarter?
componenttext: What were your exports of gasoline and diesel in the quarter?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So gasoline, we did 157,000 barrels a day of gasoline. We did 264,000 barrels a day of diesel. If you add kerosene in with that, it would be 307,000 barrels a day of total distillate.
componenttext: So gasoline, we did 157,000 barrels a day of gasoline. We did 264,000 barrels a day of diesel. If you add kerosene in with that, it would be 307,000 barrels a day of total distillate.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. One other question. This is just kind of specific to your Gulf Coast system. We just noticed that your realized margin capture rate versus your index is always better in the fourth quarter in the Gulf Coast than the other 3 quarters of the year. And
componenttext: Okay. One other question. This is just kind of specific to your Gulf Coast system. We just noticed that your realized margin capture rate versus your index is always better in the fourth quarter in the Gulf Coast than the other 3 quarters of the year. And that's been pretty consistent in the last, I don't know, 4 years running. Why is that the case? Is there any specific reason for that?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I would say certainly you get butane blending would come into play there. And so as butane has been discounted and we're able to blend it into the pool it helps our capture rates. I don't know if you have anything else?.
componenttext: Well, I would say certainly you get butane blending would come into play there. And so as butane has been discounted and we're able to blend it into the pool it helps our capture rates. I don't know if you have anything else?.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Hi, Chi. This is Lane. I'd only add, normally seasonally what you'd see is medium heavy sour discounts widen out. So when you're using sort of a standard capture rate versus light sweet, we always outperform on that as well.
componenttext: Hi, Chi. This is Lane. I'd only add, normally seasonally what you'd see is medium heavy sour discounts widen out. So when you're using sort of a standard capture rate versus light sweet, we always outperform on that as well.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Faisel Khan from Citigroup.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question. On the timing of the projects that came online in the fourth quarter, so the Corpus Christi crude unit, the hydrocracker and the expansion of McKee, and then also Line 9B sort of highlighted that because that was a December startup.
componenttext: Just a quick question. On the timing of the projects that came online in the fourth quarter, so the Corpus Christi crude unit, the hydrocracker and the expansion of McKee, and then also Line 9B sort of highlighted that because that was a December startup. How did those start up in the quarter? I'm just trying to understand so what the contribution was from the commissioning of these assets in the quarter, just so we get sort of the uplift right going into '16.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Lane. So McKee -- we finished that project, which really took us about 2 years to fully implement the entire scope of that, which was 2 things. One was it was an energy efficiency project and distillate recovery and the second was sort of plus cru
componenttext: This is Lane. So McKee -- we finished that project, which really took us about 2 years to fully implement the entire scope of that, which was 2 things. One was it was an energy efficiency project and distillate recovery and the second was sort of plus crude grade. And we finished it in October. And I assume that's what you're after, you're sort of after, the time. Okay. And Port Arthur, again, the hydrocracker was down in October and then we replaced the catalyst and did the expansion. And then Corpus Christi really started up gearing sort of early to mid-December. So you wouldn't have seen anything with respect to fourth quarter improvement. That's really going to be entirely a 2016 thing.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, got you. So McKee, we would have seen a full contribution in the quarter, but it sounds like Port Arthur was down in October, and then of course nothing from the Corpus.
componenttext: Okay, got you. So McKee, we would have seen a full contribution in the quarter, but it sounds like Port Arthur was down in October, and then of course nothing from the Corpus.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Corpus, right. Nothing from Corpus and obviously St. Charles we're doing right now.
componenttext: Corpus, right. Nothing from Corpus and obviously St. Charles we're doing right now.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then right now, given where crude prices are in Canada versus the Atlantic Basin, is it -- does it makes sense to max out Line 9B? Or where are we with the market in terms of how we would benefit from that?
componenttext: Okay. And then right now, given where crude prices are in Canada versus the Atlantic Basin, is it -- does it makes sense to max out Line 9B? Or where are we with the market in terms of how we would benefit from that?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so I would say on Line 9B we're seeing some value in the Bakken that we're running. Most of the Western Canadian light sweets we're not seeing a material difference in [indiscernible] or uplift in running those barrels compared to foreign light sweet
componenttext: Yes, so I would say on Line 9B we're seeing some value in the Bakken that we're running. Most of the Western Canadian light sweets we're not seeing a material difference in [indiscernible] or uplift in running those barrels compared to foreign light sweets that we can import into Québec.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Our next question comes from Vikas Dwivedi from Macquarie Group.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016

componenttext: Quick question on gasoline and ethanol. Now they've been inverted for a while. Does that change how you guys blend or any of the approach to the overall gasoline operation, given sort of upside down from normal?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Want to take it, Martin?
componenttext: Want to take it, Martin?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: This is Martin Parrish. Well, it's really the impact on the blending margin, not on the refiner's margin. Ethanol is selling at about its blend value. Everything is kind of at its blend value that's high octane. You have to remember that the blender still
componenttext: This is Martin Parrish. Well, it's really the impact on the blending margin, not on the refiner's margin. Ethanol is selling at about its blend value. Everything is kind of at its blend value that's high octane. You have to remember that the blender still gets the rent if they choose to blend ethanol. So it kind of works out. We don't -- I would say there's really no impact [indiscernible].

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. And then coming back to the alky plant, the C5 technology, is that also a call on kind of an oversupply to ethane or ethylene market down the road?
componenttext: Got it. And then coming back to the alky plant, the C5 technology, is that also a call on kind of an oversupply to ethane or ethylene market down the road?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: I don't want to -- it's not a call. It's just really -- you look at the whole NGL market, it's been pretty -- it's been long. We have -- and it's really a view that we can take and move NGLs into the gasoline pool, and we can do it by alkylating amylenes
componenttext: I don't want to -- it's not a call. It's just really -- you look at the whole NGL market, it's been pretty -- it's been long. We have -- and it's really a view that we can take and move NGLs into the gasoline pool, and we can do it by alkylating amylenes in the refinery, which is a little bit different. And it makes a good, high octane, low RVP component, which then in turn allows us to blend additional butane in the summer in particular.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. We were just thinking if it was a call, it's a -- it would be a great call. I think we're going to be drowning in the lighter end of the NGL barrel for a long time.
componenttext: Got it. We were just thinking if it was a call, it's a -- it would be a great call. I think we're going to be drowning in the lighter end of the NGL barrel for a long time.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: So I mean, I wouldn't tie it to ethane. It's the whole NGL space, right, which we believe is actually long going forward, too.
componenttext: So I mean, I wouldn't tie it to ethane. It's the whole NGL space, right, which we believe is actually long going forward, too.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: We have a question from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: We have a question from Brad Heffern from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Circling back to VLP, I'm just curious, we all know the uncertainty and the turmoil in the capital markets, but it seems like the strategy is basically unchanged, and you have 55% of the growth in 2016 in terms of budget going into VLP. At what point do y
componenttext: Circling back to VLP, I'm just curious, we all know the uncertainty and the turmoil in the capital markets, but it seems like the strategy is basically unchanged, and you have 55% of the growth in 2016 in terms of budget going into VLP. At what point do you think about that and maybe re-examine the pace of growth, given that the market doesn't necessarily seem to be rewarding growth as much as it once was?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we'll continue to -- that's our -- right now our plan is to do the $1 billion, but we'll continue to examine and monitor the markets as we move through the year. I mean, it is very challenging right now. We do have our revolver, that we could
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we'll continue to -- that's our -- right now our plan is to do the $1 billion, but we'll continue to examine and monitor the markets as we move through the year. I mean, it is very challenging right now. We do have our revolver, that we could use that as a financing source for some of the drops. So the bank market seems to be a little bit more attractive than the capital markets at this point in time.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Brad, let me just add to what Mike said, though. The capital that we're investing in logistics assets at Valero Energy are assets that can't be dropped to VLP. So we'll continue to build the droppable EBITDA base. But the motivation behind it, and we've s
componenttext:
Brad, let me just add to what Mike said, though. The capital that we're investing in logistics assets at Valero Energy are assets that can't be dropped to VLP. So we'll continue to build the droppable EBITDA base. But the motivation behind it, and we've shared this before, the motivation behind Valero investing in logistics assets are projects that benefit Valero's core business, its core refining business. They're projects that help us optimize our operations. And we're not taking flyers on projects that we wouldn't be willing to commit contractually long term to. 
And so again, the things we're investing in today, for example the Diamond pipeline, I mean, that is going to be a direct benefit to the Memphis refinery and provide crude optionality there that they don't currently have today. So this is a -- it's a long game. And even though markets are challenged right now, I don't think we should sit here and throw the baby out with the bath water and totally redirect strategies to try to accommodate it. 
The other thing that Mike hasn't mentioned is that VLP is in a great position. They've got very high coverage ratios. To maintain distribution growth at the targets we've talked about is not going to be an issue. And here again, we're running the business to continue to improve the business and drive EPS growth at VLO, and VLP is going to go along for the ride. So anyway, that's just a little more color.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think that's clear. And then thinking about logistics opportunities as well, I'm curious, obviously that -- looking into the crude export band and seeing it's negative for refiners in general, but I would think there might be some opportunities to
componenttext: Yes. I think that's clear. And then thinking about logistics opportunities as well, I'm curious, obviously that -- looking into the crude export band and seeing it's negative for refiners in general, but I would think there might be some opportunities to present themselves to Valero, given the amount of dock space and general footprint in the Gulf Coast. Have you thought along those lines yet?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, I -- this is Rich Lashway. Yes, we've started up that opportunity. We're in conversations with a lot of different parties on projects that they have that they're willing to share now that they might not have been in the past. And so we could see qui
componenttext: Well, I -- this is Rich Lashway. Yes, we've started up that opportunity. We're in conversations with a lot of different parties on projects that they have that they're willing to share now that they might not have been in the past. And so we could see quite a bit of opportunity out there, given not just the declining crude prices, but also the export opportunity.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: And our last question is a follow-up question from Paul Cheng from Barclays.
componenttext: And our last question is a follow-up question from Paul Cheng from Barclays.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Maybe this is for Gary. Gary, just curious. The crude inventory bill over the last several weeks, quite substantial. Do you have any rough idea that was this split between the financial buyer buying it to take advantage on the Contango curve? Or what perc
componenttext: Maybe this is for Gary. Gary, just curious. The crude inventory bill over the last several weeks, quite substantial. Do you have any rough idea that was this split between the financial buyer buying it to take advantage on the Contango curve? Or what percentage is the operator actually, the refiner, then, who are building inventory here?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I don't suspect it's a lot of refiners building inventory. Most of our tankage and most refiners' tankage is more operational in nature. And so it's hard to really utilize that tankage for a Contango play. So most of that you'd see some inventory bui
componenttext: Yes, I don't suspect it's a lot of refiners building inventory. Most of our tankage and most refiners' tankage is more operational in nature. And so it's hard to really utilize that tankage for a Contango play. So most of that you'd see some inventory building cushion. But I don't know that I really could comment in terms of the build. I think what we had happen is LLS got into premium to a foreign light sweet alternative and Valero, along with many other refiners, started buying light sweet and caused the inventory to build. And certainly the market structures incentivize people to store as well.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q4 2015 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. Yolanda, I think that was the last of the questions. So we want to thank everyone for calling in today. And please feel free to call me and Karen if you guys have further follow-up questions. Thank you.
componenttext: Okay. Yolanda, I think that was the last of the questions. So we want to thank everyone for calling in today. And please feel free to call me and Karen if you guys have further follow-up questions. Thank you.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay, the second question maybe this is for [ph]. In the first quarter, your systemwide margin capture rate versus your benchmark is about 62%. In the first quarter last year, it's about 70%. And you average in 2015, 2014 is about 72% and 67%. So just cur
componenttext: Okay, the second question maybe this is for [ph]. In the first quarter, your systemwide margin capture rate versus your benchmark is about 62%. In the first quarter last year, it's about 70%. And you average in 2015, 2014 is about 72% and 67%. So just curious that in the first quarter this year, the much lower margin capture rate, how much is related to just the different pricing and volume in the macro fund fog and how much is related to more company specific reasons? Any kind of insight would be great.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Gary. I can start I guess it's hard to go into a lot of detail on the capture rate. So certainly I invite you to follow-up with Karen and John after the call. But some high-level things I can tell intro-mac volume, there really was a negativ
componenttext: Paul, this is Gary. I can start I guess it's hard to go into a lot of detail on the capture rate. So certainly I invite you to follow-up with Karen and John after the call. But some high-level things I can tell intro-mac volume, there really was a negative impact on volume variance for our refineries. Actually, we would show that the volume variance was slightly positive for the quarter. So what you're seeing on the capture rate is all market driven. On a high level, there's a few things I would point to that higher cost RIN certainly had an impact on our capture rates. The butane differential, the gasoline was much more narrow in the first quarter than what we saw last year. That had an impact on our capture rates. In the North Atlantic Basin, when you look at our crude costs relative to Brent, the narrow Brent and WTI impact on our crude costs most importantly, in Québec. Also the Western Canadian crude, the Syncrude were more expensive in the first course. So the volumes coming of Line 9. So we had crude cost impact to our North Atlantic Basin system. And the only thing that really operationally we have the cut down on the West Coast for a planned turnaround. So our capture rates there were down a little bit as well but those are some of the real key factors.

componenttext: First question on the Gulf Coast. Your crude slate clearly shifted more towards mediums. In your slide deck, you have given a range historically for heavies of about 24% to 37% over time and you're at the lower end of that range, 24% in the first quarter. And that was actually down year-over-year. So I know you talked about from medium and heavy discounts becoming available. We're there any onetime factors that led you to have actually lower heavies in the quarter? Or just generally how are you thinking about crude slate as we progress through the year?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, this is Gary. A Couple of things the way we report our results, we have the heavy crudes shown but we also a category we show resids. And some of those resids are actually replacements for heavy sour crude in our system. We run the resids through ou
componenttext: Phil, this is Gary. A Couple of things the way we report our results, we have the heavy crudes shown but we also a category we show resids. And some of those resids are actually replacements for heavy sour crude in our system. We run the resids through our crude unit. And so where the heavy sour crudes were down, actually, the resids we process were up. So there really wasn't a significant difference in the amount of heavy sour crude we run in the first quarter. In terms of the range, some of the things we talked about, it's not just the discounts that we're looking at, there's a rate lever associated with really publishing heavy sour crudes in our system. If we want to maximize heavy sour crudes, generally mean we're running at lower throughputs so we had to look at the discounts and also where the crack spreads are and then we do that optimization.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Got it, okay. A follow-up question just on the M&A front. With respect to refinance to the extent you're looking there, could you just to remind us how you think about regionally where you want to be adding exposure?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, if you look at areas that we feel that we could grow okay, and I'm doing this from just historical looks at different assets and how the FTC might do something. The West Coast, California in particular will be very, very difficult for us. We'
componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at areas that we feel that we could grow okay, and I'm doing this from just historical looks at different assets and how the FTC might do something. The West Coast, California in particular will be very, very difficult for us. We're not really focus there. The East Coast, we've exited and so we're not interested there. The Mid-Con, I think we would be good to go on transactions and we'd be interested in there and then, of course, U.S. Gulf Coast. And when we look at the acquisitions, we look at them from the perspective of where can we create the greatest synergies. And with the portfolio of fastest that we have in the U.S. Gulf Coast, we believe that we can greet synergies around feedstock and product movements there perhaps better than anywhere else. Now if we -- so that would be the U.S. side. If we go over to Europe, I think that we'd be interested in assets in markets like the U.K., where we've got a presence today and we can bolt something on and support it out of the London office. We're not interested in a lot of the countries in Western Europe just because of the nature of the assets and then the issues that go along with owning assets in those markets. And then I really think from our perspective, the Far East is off the table. So if in a nutshell, the U.S. Gulf Coast will be interesting, the Mid-Con and the U.S. will be interesting. The U.K. would be interesting and that would be our primary focus.

componenttext: I think, going forward, the thing we're looking at is our export. componenttext: So you came in as CEO really talking about cash returns, big jump in the dividend. I'm not quite sure why today somebody is saying you're going to buy stuff. If I missed something, is that mostly talking about or is this change in tone? And further to that, a macro follow up. It seems like we've got really good environment in terms of demand and everything else out there particularly for you guys with the heavy spared -- the heavy sour. Why margins are not better? And then given -- is that related to oversupplied do you think, which would further underline that you wouldn't want to be growing in this market? You would want to be shrinking?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I'll go first. You know Paul, M&A is something that we have in our capital allocation framework for the last 2 years and that really hasn't changed. Now it seems like you and your peers are the ones that are interested in that perhaps more than
componenttext: All right. I'll go first. You know Paul, M&A is something that we have in our capital allocation framework for the last 2 years and that really hasn't changed. Now it seems like you and your peers are the ones that are interested in that perhaps more than we are. But we look at our approach of trying to drive EPS growth over the next 3 to 5 years, it's really multifaceted and includes growth investments in refining and midstream. We also look at M&A, and we look at share repurchases. And we've got a really good pipeline of refining projects that are underdeveloped or are under development. Now we don't want to get out over our skis, so we don't really discuss the specifics on these projects that are in development until we've gone further down the approval process. But we do have a bunch of great projects that exceeded the 25% IRR hurdle rate that we've talked about and we'll try to do as many of those projects as we find. Midstream investments are of interest. They got a lower hurdle rate as you would expect, but they'll drive earnings growth through optimization. So these are critical to us also. Then when we look at the discretionary uses of cash, M&A fits into that category for us. And really what I just want to communicate on that is the assets that we would look at there, Paul, will be those that create synergy and will be accretive to the company. We've got a great portfolio today, and we do have that tension between the used, the discretionary use of cash via this framework that we put in place. And we're not going to do an acquisition and that's why you consider we haven't pulled the trigger. We're not going to do an acquisition if we believe that it's more accretive to do a share repurchase. So anyway, returning cash to shareholders hasn't lost its priority at all from our perspective. It's just we are looking at that growth projects and M&A as a competitive use of funds. So with that, Gary, you want to answer it. . .

componenttext: Yes, I think so you have a couple of key factors. we keep pointing on the distillate side, the warmer weather in the United States and Northwest Europe certainly hindered this demand coming through the winter, and so it created this overhang we're living with today. And the other thing that happened is the combination of relatively strong crack spreads in December and January instead of higher utilization than what we typically see. In combination, the strong during the market ahd refiners that typically aren't running high utilization in December and January running at high utilization and selling their product forward. So those things kind all contributed to build some inventory and it will just take us a little while to work that inventory off.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Venezuela was very important piece of our crude supply situation. We've had a very good long-standing relationship with the vasa. What we've seen is we really haven't seen a decrease in oil coming out of the country. Wad we have seen is a with som
componenttext: Yes, so Venezuela was very important piece of our crude supply situation. We've had a very good long-standing relationship with the vasa. What we've seen is we really haven't seen a decrease in oil coming out of the country. Wad we have seen is a with some of the rolling power outages that they've had, the grades of oil are changing. So we're seeing a greater percentage of diluted crude oil and less of some of the synthetic crude goes into our system but our system is robust not to be able to absorb that. And so we buy those barrels and continue to run them into our system.

componenttext: Yes, Jeff, so we're certainly seeing that. In the Iranian barrels, of course, we don't run any Iranian barrels but what we have seen there is kind of rebalancing in the market. And then yes, we're certainly seeing a lot more Saudi barrels flowing this way. We had decreased our Saudi volumes but continue to put barrels in the market and your competitive we are ramping up those back up in our system as well.

componenttext: I really never heard anybody use generous and FTC in the same context. What I would describe them as a very reasonable group, quite honestly, and we have a lot of dealings with them over the years as we have done acquisitions. I believe that what they would look at not only for Valero but for anybody is your ability to restrict trade in a particular market. And because the Gulf Coast is so long and so oversupplied and the barrels tend to move throughout the U.S. and the abroad, you're not going to run into a situation whereby having a more significant concentration in the Gulf Coast. You would run into a situation where you could manipulate market, it just wouldn't be possible. So anyway, I really don't think they have a problem with additional Gulf Coast exposure for Valero.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2016 First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. My name is Bianca, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to your host, Mr. John Locke. Mr. John, you may begin.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our Executive Vice President of Refining Operations and Engineering; Jay Browning, our Executive Vice President and General Counsel; and several other members of Valero's senior management team.
If you have not received the earnings release and would like a copy, you can find one on our website at valero.com. Also attached to the earnings release are tables that provide additional financial information on our business segments.
If you have any questions after reviewing these tables, please feel free to contact our Investor Relations team after the call. I would like to direct your attention to the forward-looking statement disclaimer contained in the press release.
In summary, it says that statements in the press release and on this conference call that state the company's or management's expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions under federal securities laws. There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations, including those we've described in our filings with the SEC.
Now I will turn the call over to Joe for a few opening remarks.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. The first quarter presented us with challenging markets, with gasoline and diesel margins under pressure for most of the quarter. A bright spot was the performance of our team as we continue to operate safel
componenttext:
Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. The first quarter presented us with challenging markets, with gasoline and diesel margins under pressure for most of the quarter. A bright spot was the performance of our team as we continue to operate safely and reliably. 
What I'd like to do this morning is take a few minutes to discuss our strategic initiatives that we believe will continue to drive long-term value creation and then share some color on what we're seeing in the markets. 
First, is the core of everything we do, is the relentless focus on safety and reliability. Our dedication and persistence here is what keeps our people and communities safe, our operations reliable, our cash operating costs lowest among the peer group. Having low-cost operations is a major advantage in our industry where product margins can be quite volatile. As a disciplined operator, we are able to run profitably in a lower margin environment as experienced in the first quarter. 
Second, we apply discipline and rigor as we evaluate and execute investments that will grow the profitability and competitiveness of our business for many years. The strategic plan that was approved by our Board of Directors last year included $2.6 billion of capital spending for 2016, approximately $1 billion was allocated to strategic investments to drive long-term earnings growth. 
Third, we're committed to delivering value to stockholders by making the right investments in our business and returning cash to our stockholders. We demonstrated this in 2015 when we delivered the highest total stockholder return among our peers for both Valero and VLP. We expect VLP to continue to be well positioned to execute its distribution growth strategy through 2017 despite volatile capital markets. 
We also continued to keep an eye on M&A. We review opportunities, and we have a list of targets that we consistently monitor. We consider M&A a discretionary use of cash, so there's a healthy tension when evaluating M&A opportunities versus other alternative uses. Of course, we can't comment specifically on M&A but we are diligently reviewing opportunities. 
For cash returns in 2016, which is made up of dividends and buybacks, we've extended our 2015 payout target of 75% of net income. In January, we increased the quarterly dividend by 20% to $0.60 a share and we remain focused on maintaining a dividend payout at the high end of our peer group. We're confident in Valero's ability to fund investments in future growth and to meet its payout target. Lastly, let me sure some color on the current market. Already this year, we've been in a lot of conversations about various market topics, including gasoline demand resurgence, strength, diesel length, domestic crude supply and crude storage levels. As you know, markets for Valero's feedstocks and products are dynamic. Our high complexity refineries, system flexibility, advantage locations and low cash cost operations enable us to maximize earnings under challenging market conditions. 
On the crude supply side, we're seeing more medial sour crude coming into the market. As a result, we're seeing healthy medium and heavy sour crude discounts. We also have greater access to domestic sweet crudes with the logistics build out in the U.S. allowing domestic production to clear the Mid-Continent region that reach large Gulf Coast refining center. 
On the demand side, continued GDP growth in the product prices should continue to support demand. In the U.S., we've seen gasoline demand continue to growth. We've encouraged by increased vehicle miles traveled and double-digit percentage increases in SUV and truck purchases in the U.S. and key countries around the globe. This commitment nobody was good albeit in the U.S., it's been fairly flat. While distillate margins were pressured near term due to unseasonably warm weather in North America and Europe, distillate demand in Latin America remains robust. 
Overall, we still have structural refine product supply challenges in South America and in developing countries, which we don't expect to be resolved in the near-term. With our low-cost Gulf Coast refining presence, we have the ability to compete in markets all over the globe, we also have the opportunity to optimize our system and supply, the Atlantic Basin with our refineries and wealth in Québec city. In fact, we generated another quarter of solid distillates and gasoline export volumes. 
In summary, we still have significant crude supply from ample natural gas availability and growing global petroleum demand that's outpacing refining capacity additions. We don't see this changing anytime soon. So although the markets will be challenging at times, the longer-term macro outlook remains favorable. 
So with that, John, I'll hand the call back to you.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Moving on to the results. Net income was $495 million or $1.05 per share for the first quarter of 2016. Excluding an after-tax, lower cost of market inventory valuation benefit of $212 million or $0.45 per share, we recorded first quarter
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Moving on to the results. Net income was $495 million or $1.05 per share for the first quarter of 2016. Excluding an after-tax, lower cost of market inventory valuation benefit of $212 million or $0.45 per share, we recorded first quarter 2016 adjusted net income of $283 million or $0.60 per share. This compares to $964 million for $1.87 per share for the first quarter of 2015. For reconciliations of actual to adjusted amounts, please refer to Page 6 of the financial tables that accompany our release. 
Adjusted operating income for the refining segment in the first quarter of 2016 was $695 million or $946 million lower than in the first quarter of 2015. Margins were pressured downward primarily due to weaker distillate margins given high refinery run rates across the industry, product inventory builds and unseasonably warm weather. Other headwinds on refining margins included narrower domestic light sweet crude oil discount versus the Brent benchmark, low fuel oil and petrochemical product margins and elevated costs for RINs credits. 
Low crude oil prices continue to travel slowdowns in North America on drilling and production, which coupled with in excess of pipeline take a we capacity in the Mid-Continent region, led to tighter discounts for crude oil relative to Brent. Lower energy cost supported by robust North American natural gas production partly offset these factors. 
Our refineries operated at 96% throughput capacity utilization in the first quarter of 2016 and throughput volumes average 2.9 million barrels per day, which was 169,000 barrels per day higher than in the first quarter of 2015. 
Refining cash operating expenses of $3.55 per barrel were $0.40 per barrel lower than in the first quarter of 2015 mostly due to higher throughput volumes and lower energy costs. 
In the ethanol segment earned $9 million of adjusted operating income in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $12 million in the first quarter of 2015. The low crude oil and gasoline price environment challenged ethanol margins but with the recent recovery in prices, ethanol margins had modestly improved to start the second quarter. 
For the first quarter of 2016, general and administrative expenses, excluding corporate depreciation were $156 million, net interest expense was $108 million. 
Depreciation and amortization expense was $485 million and the effective tax rate for the first quarter of 2016 was 30%. The effective tax rate was lower than the first quarter of 2015, primarily due to higher relative earnings contribution from international operations with lower statutory tax rates. 
Regarding our balance sheet, at quarter-end, we had $7.3 billion of total debt and $3.8 billion of cash and temporary cash investments, of which $102 million was held by VLP. Valero's debt-to-capitalization ratio net of $2 billion in cash was 20%. We had $5.5 billion of available liquidity, excluding cash, of which $575 million was only available to VLP. 
Cash flows in the first quarter included $479 million of capital investments, of which $161 million was for turnarounds and catalyst. For 2016, we expect to invest $1.6 billion of capital to sustain the business and $1 billion for refining asset optimization and logistics to drive long-term earnings growth. 
With respect to our refining growth strategy, the new Corpus Christi crude unit, which was completed late last year operated as planned and delivered approximately $35 million of EBITDA in the first quarter. 
We completed the St. Charles hydrocracker expansion in March and the new Houston crude unit is on track to start up in the second quarter. The Houston alkylation project, which was approved in January is now undergoing detailed engineering and procurement. Completion of the alkylation unit is expected on the first half of 2019. 
Now moving to  financing activities. We returned $547 million in cash to our stockholders in the first quarter, which included $282 million in dividend payments and $265 million for the repurchase of 3.8 million shares of Valero common stock. We had $1.1 billion of remaining share repurchase authorization as of March 31, 2016. Our regular quarterly cash dividend is now $0.60 per share. 
We continue to target a payout of 75% of annual net income for 2016. For modeling our second quarter operations, we expect throughput volumes to fall within the following ranges: Gulf Coast at 1.59 million to 1.64 million barrels per day; Mid-Continent at 430,000 to 450,000 barrels per day; West Coast at 260,000 to 280,000 barrels per day; and North Atlantic at 450,000 to 470,000 barrels per day. 
Refining cash operating expenses are estimated at approximately $3.75 per barrel for the second quarter. Based on today's market prices, we expect costs relating to meeting our biofuel blending obligations to be between $750 million and $850 million for 2015. This is primarily related to RINs in the U.S. The ethanol segment is expected to produce a total of 3.8 million gallons per day. 
Operating expenses should average $0.37 per gallon, which includes $0.05 per gallon for depreciation and amortization. G&A expenses for the second quarter, excluding corporate depreciation are expected to be approximately $165 million and net interest expense should be about $110 million. Total depreciation and amortization expense is estimated at $465 million and our effective tax rate is expected to be 31%. This concludes our opening remarks. [Operator Instructions]

componenttext: Yes, Blake. Sure, this is Mike. Before we get into that target, let me start of pay talking about the Capital Market. VLC does not needed to execute any drop to meet its 25% disposition growth through 2017. So VLP does not need to access the capital markets. That being said, we believe the capital markets both debt and equity are open for MLP, particularly high-quality MLPs like VLP. The cost of issuing debt or equity, however, remains more expensive than historical level. The good news is that VLP is well positioned, with strong distribution company -- distribution coverage and does not need access the capital markets and is price environment. Therefore, we are going to revised our drop-down guidance to $500 million $750 million. We could execute drabs in this range without going to capital market. We are going to continue to prepare for 1 day in the drop and will be ready to execute 1 day and then drop. Capital Market improves. From a Valero Energy perspective, regardless of whether or not we drop $500 million or $1 billion worth of assets this year to VLP, this amount will not materially changed our view on our payout guidance.

componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Gary. I can start I guess it's hard to go into a lot of detail on the capture rate. So certainly I invite you to follow-up with Karen and John after the call. But some high-level things I can tell intro-mac volume, there really was a negativ
componenttext: Paul, this is Gary. I can start I guess it's hard to go into a lot of detail on the capture rate. So certainly I invite you to follow-up with Karen and John after the call. But some high-level things I can tell intro-mac volume, there really was a negative impact on volume variance for our refineries. Actually, we would show that the volume variance was slightly positive for the quarter. So what you're seeing on the capture rate is all market driven. On a high level, there's a few things I would point to that higher cost RIN certainly had an impact on our capture rates. The butane differential, the gasoline was much more narrow in the first quarter than what we saw last year. That had an impact on our capture rates. In the North Atlantic Basin, when you look at our crude costs relative to Brent, the narrow Brent and WTI impact on our crude costs most importantly, in Québec. Also the Western Canadian crude, the Syncrude were more expensive in the first course. So the volumes coming of Line 9. So we had crude cost impact to our North Atlantic Basin system. And the only thing that really operationally we have the cut down on the West Coast for a planned turnaround. So our capture rates there were down a little bit as well but those are some of the real key factors.

componenttext: First question on the Gulf Coast. Your crude slate clearly shifted more towards mediums. In your slide deck, you have given a range historically for heavies of about 24% to 37% over time and you're at the lower end of that range, 24% in the first quarter. And that was actually down year-over-year. So I know you talked about from medium and heavy discounts becoming available. We're there any onetime factors that led you to have actually lower heavies in the quarter? Or just generally how are you thinking about crude slate as we progress through the year?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, this is Gary. A Couple of things the way we report our results, we have the heavy crudes shown but we also a category we show resids. And some of those resids are actually replacements for heavy sour crude in our system. We run the resids through ou
componenttext: Phil, this is Gary. A Couple of things the way we report our results, we have the heavy crudes shown but we also a category we show resids. And some of those resids are actually replacements for heavy sour crude in our system. We run the resids through our crude unit. And so where the heavy sour crudes were down, actually, the resids we process were up. So there really wasn't a significant difference in the amount of heavy sour crude we run in the first quarter. In terms of the range, some of the things we talked about, it's not just the discounts that we're looking at, there's a rate lever associated with really publishing heavy sour crudes in our system. If we want to maximize heavy sour crudes, generally mean we're running at lower throughputs so we had to look at the discounts and also where the crack spreads are and then we do that optimization.
