headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, if you look at areas that we feel that we could grow okay, and I'm doing this from just historical looks at different assets and how the FTC might do something. The West Coast, California in particular will be very, very difficult for us. We'
componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at areas that we feel that we could grow okay, and I'm doing this from just historical looks at different assets and how the FTC might do something. The West Coast, California in particular will be very, very difficult for us. We're not really focus there. The East Coast, we've exited and so we're not interested there. The Mid-Con, I think we would be good to go on transactions and we'd be interested in there and then, of course, U.S. Gulf Coast. And when we look at the acquisitions, we look at them from the perspective of where can we create the greatest synergies. And with the portfolio of fastest that we have in the U.S. Gulf Coast, we believe that we can greet synergies around feedstock and product movements there perhaps better than anywhere else. Now if we -- so that would be the U.S. side. If we go over to Europe, I think that we'd be interested in assets in markets like the U.K., where we've got a presence today and we can bolt something on and support it out of the London office. We're not interested in a lot of the countries in Western Europe just because of the nature of the assets and then the issues that go along with owning assets in those markets. And then I really think from our perspective, the Far East is off the table. So if in a nutshell, the U.S. Gulf Coast will be interesting, the Mid-Con and the U.S. will be interesting. The U.K. would be interesting and that would be our primary focus.

componenttext: So you came in as CEO really talking about cash returns, big jump in the dividend. I'm not quite sure why today somebody is saying you're going to buy stuff. If I missed something, is that mostly talking about or is this change in tone? And further to that, a macro follow up. It seems like we've got really good environment in terms of demand and everything else out there particularly for you guys with the heavy spared -- the heavy sour. Why margins are not better? And then given -- is that related to oversupplied do you think, which would further underline that you wouldn't want to be growing in this market? You would want to be shrinking?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I'll go first. You know Paul, M&A is something that we have in our capital allocation framework for the last 2 years and that really hasn't changed. Now it seems like you and your peers are the ones that are interested in that perhaps more than
componenttext: All right. I'll go first. You know Paul, M&A is something that we have in our capital allocation framework for the last 2 years and that really hasn't changed. Now it seems like you and your peers are the ones that are interested in that perhaps more than we are. But we look at our approach of trying to drive EPS growth over the next 3 to 5 years, it's really multifaceted and includes growth investments in refining and midstream. We also look at M&A, and we look at share repurchases. And we've got a really good pipeline of refining projects that are underdeveloped or are under development. Now we don't want to get out over our skis, so we don't really discuss the specifics on these projects that are in development until we've gone further down the approval process. But we do have a bunch of great projects that exceeded the 25% IRR hurdle rate that we've talked about and we'll try to do as many of those projects as we find. Midstream investments are of interest. They got a lower hurdle rate as you would expect, but they'll drive earnings growth through optimization. So these are critical to us also. Then when we look at the discretionary uses of cash, M&A fits into that category for us. And really what I just want to communicate on that is the assets that we would look at there, Paul, will be those that create synergy and will be accretive to the company. We've got a great portfolio today, and we do have that tension between the used, the discretionary use of cash via this framework that we put in place. And we're not going to do an acquisition and that's why you consider we haven't pulled the trigger. We're not going to do an acquisition if we believe that it's more accretive to do a share repurchase. So anyway, returning cash to shareholders hasn't lost its priority at all from our perspective. It's just we are looking at that growth projects and M&A as a competitive use of funds. So with that, Gary, you want to answer it. . .

componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so you have a couple of key factors. we keep pointing on the distillate side, the warmer weather in the United States and Northwest Europe certainly hindered this demand coming through the winter, and so it created this overhang we're living
componenttext: Yes, I think so you have a couple of key factors. we keep pointing on the distillate side, the warmer weather in the United States and Northwest Europe certainly hindered this demand coming through the winter, and so it created this overhang we're living with today. And the other thing that happened is the combination of relatively strong crack spreads in December and January instead of higher utilization than what we typically see. In combination, the strong during the market ahd refiners that typically aren't running high utilization in December and January running at high utilization and selling their product forward. So those things kind all contributed to build some inventory and it will just take us a little while to work that inventory off.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Venezuela was very important piece of our crude supply situation. We've had a very good long-standing relationship with the vasa. What we've seen is we really haven't seen a decrease in oil coming out of the country. Wad we have seen is a with som
componenttext: Yes, so Venezuela was very important piece of our crude supply situation. We've had a very good long-standing relationship with the vasa. What we've seen is we really haven't seen a decrease in oil coming out of the country. Wad we have seen is a with some of the rolling power outages that they've had, the grades of oil are changing. So we're seeing a greater percentage of diluted crude oil and less of some of the synthetic crude goes into our system but our system is robust not to be able to absorb that. And so we buy those barrels and continue to run them into our system.

And then yes, we're certainly seeing a lot more Saudi barrels flowing this way. We had decreased our Saudi volumes but continue to put barrels in the market and your competitive we are ramping up those back up in our system as well.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: I really never heard anybody use generous and FTC in the same context. What I would describe them as a very reasonable group, quite honestly, and we have a lot of dealings with them over the years as we have done acquisitions. I believe that what they would look at not only for Valero but for anybody is your ability to restrict trade in a particular market. And because the Gulf Coast is so long and so oversupplied and the barrels tend to move throughout the U.S. and the abroad, you're not going to run into a situation whereby having a more significant concentration in the Gulf Coast. You would run into a situation where you could manipulate market, it just wouldn't be possible. So anyway, I really don't think they have a problem with additional Gulf Coast exposure for Valero.

componenttext: Yes, Brad, this is Gary. So you know in the first quarter, we did 249,000 barrels a day of diesel. If you include jet kerosene with that, we're up up to 295,000 barrels a day. It opened back up and has remained open. So I think that you'll see a little more you volume going into Europe. But we're still seeing very good Latin American demand for diesel as well moving forward.

componenttext: Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2016 First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. My name is Bianca, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the call over to your host, Mr. John Locke. Mr. John, you may begin.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our Executive Vice President of Refining Operations and Engineering; Jay Browning, our Executive Vice President and General Counsel; and several other members of Valero's senior management team.
If you have not received the earnings release and would like a copy, you can find one on our website at valero.com. Also attached to the earnings release are tables that provide additional financial information on our business segments.
If you have any questions after reviewing these tables, please feel free to contact our Investor Relations team after the call. I would like to direct your attention to the forward-looking statement disclaimer contained in the press release.
In summary, it says that statements in the press release and on this conference call that state the company's or management's expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the Safe Harbor provisions under federal securities laws. There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations, including those we've described in our filings with the SEC.
Now I will turn the call over to Joe for a few opening remarks.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. The first quarter presented us with challenging markets, with gasoline and diesel margins under pressure for most of the quarter. A bright spot was the performance of our team as we continue to operate safel
componenttext:
Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. The first quarter presented us with challenging markets, with gasoline and diesel margins under pressure for most of the quarter. A bright spot was the performance of our team as we continue to operate safely and reliably. 
What I'd like to do this morning is take a few minutes to discuss our strategic initiatives that we believe will continue to drive long-term value creation and then share some color on what we're seeing in the markets. 
First, is the core of everything we do, is the relentless focus on safety and reliability. Our dedication and persistence here is what keeps our people and communities safe, our operations reliable, our cash operating costs lowest among the peer group. Having low-cost operations is a major advantage in our industry where product margins can be quite volatile. As a disciplined operator, we are able to run profitably in a lower margin environment as experienced in the first quarter. 
Second, we apply discipline and rigor as we evaluate and execute investments that will grow the profitability and competitiveness of our business for many years. The strategic plan that was approved by our Board of Directors last year included $2.6 billion of capital spending for 2016, approximately $1 billion was allocated to strategic investments to drive long-term earnings growth. 
Third, we're committed to delivering value to stockholders by making the right investments in our business and returning cash to our stockholders. We demonstrated this in 2015 when we delivered the highest total stockholder return among our peers for both Valero and VLP. We expect VLP to continue to be well positioned to execute its distribution growth strategy through 2017 despite volatile capital markets. 
We also continued to keep an eye on M&A. We review opportunities, and we have a list of targets that we consistently monitor. We consider M&A a discretionary use of cash, so there's a healthy tension when evaluating M&A opportunities versus other alternative uses. Of course, we can't comment specifically on M&A but we are diligently reviewing opportunities. 
For cash returns in 2016, which is made up of dividends and buybacks, we've extended our 2015 payout target of 75% of net income. In January, we increased the quarterly dividend by 20% to $0.60 a share and we remain focused on maintaining a dividend payout at the high end of our peer group. We're confident in Valero's ability to fund investments in future growth and to meet its payout target. Lastly, let me sure some color on the current market. Already this year, we've been in a lot of conversations about various market topics, including gasoline demand resurgence, strength, diesel length, domestic crude supply and crude storage levels. As you know, markets for Valero's feedstocks and products are dynamic. Our high complexity refineries, system flexibility, advantage locations and low cash cost operations enable us to maximize earnings under challenging market conditions. 
On the crude supply side, we're seeing more medial sour crude coming into the market. As a result, we're seeing healthy medium and heavy sour crude discounts. We also have greater access to domestic sweet crudes with the logistics build out in the U.S. allowing domestic production to clear the Mid-Continent region that reach large Gulf Coast refining center. 
On the demand side, continued GDP growth in the product prices should continue to support demand. In the U.S., we've seen gasoline demand continue to growth. We've encouraged by increased vehicle miles traveled and double-digit percentage increases in SUV and truck purchases in the U.S. and key countries around the globe. This commitment nobody was good albeit in the U.S., it's been fairly flat. While distillate margins were pressured near term due to unseasonably warm weather in North America and Europe, distillate demand in Latin America remains robust. 
Overall, we still have structural refine product supply challenges in South America and in developing countries, which we don't expect to be resolved in the near-term. With our low-cost Gulf Coast refining presence, we have the ability to compete in markets all over the globe, we also have the opportunity to optimize our system and supply, the Atlantic Basin with our refineries and wealth in Québec city. In fact, we generated another quarter of solid distillates and gasoline export volumes. 
In summary, we still have significant crude supply from ample natural gas availability and growing global petroleum demand that's outpacing refining capacity additions. We don't see this changing anytime soon. So although the markets will be challenging at times, the longer-term macro outlook remains favorable. 
So with that, John, I'll hand the call back to you.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Moving on to the results. Net income was $495 million or $1.05 per share for the first quarter of 2016. Excluding an after-tax, lower cost of market inventory valuation benefit of $212 million or $0.45 per share, we recorded first quarter
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Moving on to the results. Net income was $495 million or $1.05 per share for the first quarter of 2016. Excluding an after-tax, lower cost of market inventory valuation benefit of $212 million or $0.45 per share, we recorded first quarter 2016 adjusted net income of $283 million or $0.60 per share. This compares to $964 million for $1.87 per share for the first quarter of 2015. For reconciliations of actual to adjusted amounts, please refer to Page 6 of the financial tables that accompany our release. 
Adjusted operating income for the refining segment in the first quarter of 2016 was $695 million or $946 million lower than in the first quarter of 2015. Margins were pressured downward primarily due to weaker distillate margins given high refinery run rates across the industry, product inventory builds and unseasonably warm weather. Other headwinds on refining margins included narrower domestic light sweet crude oil discount versus the Brent benchmark, low fuel oil and petrochemical product margins and elevated costs for RINs credits. 
Low crude oil prices continue to travel slowdowns in North America on drilling and production, which coupled with in excess of pipeline take a we capacity in the Mid-Continent region, led to tighter discounts for crude oil relative to Brent. Lower energy cost supported by robust North American natural gas production partly offset these factors. 
Our refineries operated at 96% throughput capacity utilization in the first quarter of 2016 and throughput volumes average 2.9 million barrels per day, which was 169,000 barrels per day higher than in the first quarter of 2015. 
Refining cash operating expenses of $3.55 per barrel were $0.40 per barrel lower than in the first quarter of 2015 mostly due to higher throughput volumes and lower energy costs. 
In the ethanol segment earned $9 million of adjusted operating income in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $12 million in the first quarter of 2015. The low crude oil and gasoline price environment challenged ethanol margins but with the recent recovery in prices, ethanol margins had modestly improved to start the second quarter. 
For the first quarter of 2016, general and administrative expenses, excluding corporate depreciation were $156 million, net interest expense was $108 million. 
Depreciation and amortization expense was $485 million and the effective tax rate for the first quarter of 2016 was 30%. The effective tax rate was lower than the first quarter of 2015, primarily due to higher relative earnings contribution from international operations with lower statutory tax rates. 
Regarding our balance sheet, at quarter-end, we had $7.3 billion of total debt and $3.8 billion of cash and temporary cash investments, of which $102 million was held by VLP. Valero's debt-to-capitalization ratio net of $2 billion in cash was 20%. We had $5.5 billion of available liquidity, excluding cash, of which $575 million was only available to VLP. 
Cash flows in the first quarter included $479 million of capital investments, of which $161 million was for turnarounds and catalyst. For 2016, we expect to invest $1.6 billion of capital to sustain the business and $1 billion for refining asset optimization and logistics to drive long-term earnings growth. 
With respect to our refining growth strategy, the new Corpus Christi crude unit, which was completed late last year operated as planned and delivered approximately $35 million of EBITDA in the first quarter. 
We completed the St. Charles hydrocracker expansion in March and the new Houston crude unit is on track to start up in the second quarter. The Houston alkylation project, which was approved in January is now undergoing detailed engineering and procurement. Completion of the alkylation unit is expected on the first half of 2019. 
Now moving to  financing activities. We returned $547 million in cash to our stockholders in the first quarter, which included $282 million in dividend payments and $265 million for the repurchase of 3.8 million shares of Valero common stock. We had $1.1 billion of remaining share repurchase authorization as of March 31, 2016. Our regular quarterly cash dividend is now $0.60 per share. 
We continue to target a payout of 75% of annual net income for 2016. For modeling our second quarter operations, we expect throughput volumes to fall within the following ranges: Gulf Coast at 1.59 million to 1.64 million barrels per day; Mid-Continent at 430,000 to 450,000 barrels per day; West Coast at 260,000 to 280,000 barrels per day; and North Atlantic at 450,000 to 470,000 barrels per day. 
Refining cash operating expenses are estimated at approximately $3.75 per barrel for the second quarter. Based on today's market prices, we expect costs relating to meeting our biofuel blending obligations to be between $750 million and $850 million for 2015. This is primarily related to RINs in the U.S. The ethanol segment is expected to produce a total of 3.8 million gallons per day. 
Operating expenses should average $0.37 per gallon, which includes $0.05 per gallon for depreciation and amortization. G&A expenses for the second quarter, excluding corporate depreciation are expected to be approximately $165 million and net interest expense should be about $110 million. Total depreciation and amortization expense is estimated at $465 million and our effective tax rate is expected to be 31%. This concludes our opening remarks. [Operator Instructions]

componenttext: Yes, Blake. Sure, this is Mike. Before we get into that target, let me start of pay talking about the Capital Market. VLC does not needed to execute any drop to meet its 25% disposition growth through 2017. So VLP does not need to access the capital markets. That being said, we believe the capital markets both debt and equity are open for MLP, particularly high-quality MLPs like VLP. The cost of issuing debt or equity, however, remains more expensive than historical level. The good news is that VLP is well positioned, with strong distribution company -- distribution coverage and does not need access the capital markets and is price environment. Therefore, we are going to revised our drop-down guidance to $500 million $750 million. We could execute drabs in this range without going to capital market. We are going to continue to prepare for 1 day in the drop and will be ready to execute 1 day and then drop. Capital Market improves. From a Valero Energy perspective, regardless of whether or not we drop $500 million or $1 billion worth of assets this year to VLP, this amount will not materially changed our view on our payout guidance.

componenttext: Paul, this is Gary. I can start I guess it's hard to go into a lot of detail on the capture rate. So certainly I invite you to follow-up with Karen and John after the call. But some high-level things I can tell intro-mac volume, there really was a negative impact on volume variance for our refineries. The butane differential, the gasoline was much more narrow in the first quarter than what we saw last year. That had an impact on our capture rates. In the North Atlantic Basin, when you look at our crude costs relative to Brent, the narrow Brent and WTI impact on our crude costs most importantly, in Québec. Also the Western Canadian crude, the Syncrude were more expensive in the first course. So the volumes coming of Line 9. So we had crude cost impact to our North Atlantic Basin system. And the only thing that really operationally we have the cut down on the West Coast for a planned turnaround. headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, this is Gary. A Couple of things the way we report our results, we have the heavy crudes shown but we also a category we show resids. And some of those resids are actually replacements for heavy sour crude in our system. We run the resids through ou
componenttext: Phil, this is Gary. A Couple of things the way we report our results, we have the heavy crudes shown but we also a category we show resids. And some of those resids are actually replacements for heavy sour crude in our system. We run the resids through our crude unit. And so where the heavy sour crudes were down, actually, the resids we process were up. So there really wasn't a significant difference in the amount of heavy sour crude we run in the first quarter. In terms of the range, some of the things we talked about, it's not just the discounts that we're looking at, there's a rate lever associated with really publishing heavy sour crudes in our system. If we want to maximize heavy sour crudes, generally mean we're running at lower throughputs so we had to look at the discounts and also where the crack spreads are and then we do that optimization.

componenttext: Yes, I mean, if you look at areas that we feel that we could grow okay, and I'm doing this from just historical looks at different assets and how the FTC might do something. The West Coast, California in particular will be very, very difficult for us. We're not really focus there. The East Coast, we've exited and so we're not interested there. The Mid-Con, I think we would be good to go on transactions and we'd be interested in there and then, of course, U.S. Gulf Coast. And when we look at the acquisitions, we look at them from the perspective of where can we create the greatest synergies. And with the portfolio of fastest that we have in the U.S. Gulf Coast, we believe that we can greet synergies around feedstock and product movements there perhaps better than anywhere else. Now if we -- so that would be the U.S. side. If we go over to Europe, I think that we'd be interested in assets in markets like the U.K., where we've got a presence today and we can bolt something on and support it out of the London office. We're not interested in a lot of the countries in Western Europe just because of the nature of the assets and then the issues that go along with owning assets in those markets. And then I really think from our perspective, the Far East is off the table. So if in a nutshell, the U.S. Gulf Coast will be interesting, the Mid-Con and the U.S. will be interesting. The U.K. would be interesting and that would be our primary focus.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Roger, this is Gary. I think we're seeing very similar situations in regards to octane what we've seen the last couple of years. Octane starting to get tight, so we saw the rig rate in the Mid-Continent strengthen significantly. The premium rebate on the West Coast has also strengthened considerably in the last couple of weeks. So I think industry is short octand, and we'll see similar to what we've been singing the past few years.

componenttext: Okay, great. And just to follow up on your comment on the diesel demand side underpinned by the agricultural seasonality. When that -- I assume that back offs somewhat as we roll into the middle of the summer. What -- do you see any other places in the market where demand has picked up or has at least solidified versus where it was in the winter time?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I think, going forward, the thing we're looking at is our export. And so you look to us and yesterday, the JVC global refining margin showed Northwest Europe simple capacity like $0.23 margin. So it doesn't take diesel falling off much before some of that
componenttext: I think, going forward, the thing we're looking at is our export. And so you look to us and yesterday, the JVC global refining margin showed Northwest Europe simple capacity like $0.23 margin. So it doesn't take diesel falling off much before some of that low complexity capacity has to cut. And as they cut, it will open up even greater opportunities for us to export our barrels moving forward.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So you came in as CEO really talking about cash returns, big jump in the dividend. I'm not quite sure why today somebody is saying you're going to buy stuff. If I missed something, is that mostly talking about or is this change in tone? And further to tha
componenttext: So you came in as CEO really talking about cash returns, big jump in the dividend. I'm not quite sure why today somebody is saying you're going to buy stuff. If I missed something, is that mostly talking about or is this change in tone? And further to that, a macro follow up. It seems like we've got really good environment in terms of demand and everything else out there particularly for you guys with the heavy spared -- the heavy sour. Why margins are not better? And then given -- is that related to oversupplied do you think, which would further underline that you wouldn't want to be growing in this market? You would want to be shrinking?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: All right. I'll go first. You know Paul, M&A is something that we have in our capital allocation framework for the last 2 years and that really hasn't changed. Now it seems like you and your peers are the ones that are interested in that perhaps more than
componenttext: All right. I'll go first. You know Paul, M&A is something that we have in our capital allocation framework for the last 2 years and that really hasn't changed. Now it seems like you and your peers are the ones that are interested in that perhaps more than we are. But we look at our approach of trying to drive EPS growth over the next 3 to 5 years, it's really multifaceted and includes growth investments in refining and midstream. We also look at M&A, and we look at share repurchases. And we've got a really good pipeline of refining projects that are underdeveloped or are under development. Now we don't want to get out over our skis, so we don't really discuss the specifics on these projects that are in development until we've gone further down the approval process. But we do have a bunch of great projects that exceeded the 25% IRR hurdle rate that we've talked about and we'll try to do as many of those projects as we find. Midstream investments are of interest. They got a lower hurdle rate as you would expect, but they'll drive earnings growth through optimization. So these are critical to us also. Then when we look at the discretionary uses of cash, M&A fits into that category for us. And really what I just want to communicate on that is the assets that we would look at there, Paul, will be those that create synergy and will be accretive to the company. We've got a great portfolio today, and we do have that tension between the used, the discretionary use of cash via this framework that we put in place. And we're not going to do an acquisition and that's why you consider we haven't pulled the trigger. We're not going to do an acquisition if we believe that it's more accretive to do a share repurchase. So anyway, returning cash to shareholders hasn't lost its priority at all from our perspective. It's just we are looking at that growth projects and M&A as a competitive use of funds. So with that, Gary, you want to answer it. . .

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think so you have a couple of key factors. we keep pointing on the distillate side, the warmer weather in the United States and Northwest Europe certainly hindered this demand coming through the winter, and so it created this overhang we're living
componenttext: Yes, I think so you have a couple of key factors. we keep pointing on the distillate side, the warmer weather in the United States and Northwest Europe certainly hindered this demand coming through the winter, and so it created this overhang we're living with today. And the other thing that happened is the combination of relatively strong crack spreads in December and January instead of higher utilization than what we typically see. In combination, the strong during the market ahd refiners that typically aren't running high utilization in December and January running at high utilization and selling their product forward. So those things kind all contributed to build some inventory and it will just take us a little while to work that inventory off.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Understood. Very quick follow-up, can you just update us on the impact on what you're seeing in Venezuela in terms of if there's impact there and what sort of loss volumes are there and I leave it there.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, so Venezuela was very important piece of our crude supply situation. We've had a very good long-standing relationship with the vasa. What we've seen is we really haven't seen a decrease in oil coming out of the country. Wad we have seen is a with som
componenttext: Yes, so Venezuela was very important piece of our crude supply situation. We've had a very good long-standing relationship with the vasa. What we've seen is we really haven't seen a decrease in oil coming out of the country. Wad we have seen is a with some of the rolling power outages that they've had, the grades of oil are changing. So we're seeing a greater percentage of diluted crude oil and less of some of the synthetic crude goes into our system but our system is robust not to be able to absorb that. And so we buy those barrels and continue to run them into our system.

componenttext: Yes, Jeff, so we're certainly seeing that. In the Iranian barrels, of course, we don't run any Iranian barrels but what we have seen there is kind of rebalancing in the market. So some of those barrels are making their way into Europe, and we are seeing some of the Russian euros come back into the U.S. market that we haven't seen here for a while. And then yes, we're certainly seeing a lot more Saudi barrels flowing this way. We had decreased our Saudi volumes but continue to put barrels in the market and your competitive we are ramping up those back up in our system as well.

componenttext: Yes, I agree. What you've really seen is a substitution somewhat of domestic light sweet for Middle East medium sours. The big switch has been a domestic light sweet for Middle East medium sour.

componenttext: Okay. I hate to hop on M&A because I recognize the opportunity that give callers limited. headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I really never heard anybody use generous and FTC in the same context. What I would describe them as a very reasonable group, quite honestly, and we have a lot of dealings with them over the years as we have done acquisitions. I believe that what they wou
componenttext: I really never heard anybody use generous and FTC in the same context. What I would describe them as a very reasonable group, quite honestly, and we have a lot of dealings with them over the years as we have done acquisitions. I believe that what they would look at not only for Valero but for anybody is your ability to restrict trade in a particular market. And because the Gulf Coast is so long and so oversupplied and the barrels tend to move throughout the U.S. and the abroad, you're not going to run into a situation whereby having a more significant concentration in the Gulf Coast. You would run into a situation where you could manipulate market, it just wouldn't be possible. So anyway, I really don't think they have a problem with additional Gulf Coast exposure for Valero.

componenttext: Yes, Brad, this is Gary. So you know in the first quarter, we did 249,000 barrels a day of diesel. If you include jet kerosene with that, we're up up to 295,000 barrels a day. That was split with about 80% going to Latin America and 20% to Europe. During the first quarter, the arc to Europe was closed most of the first half of the first quarter. It opened back up and has remained open. So I think that you'll see a little more you volume going into Europe. But we're still seeing very good Latin American demand for diesel as well moving forward.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2016 First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. My name is Bianca, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. I will now turn the
componenttext:
Welcome to the Valero Energy Corporation Reports 2016 First Quarter Earnings Results Conference Call. My name is Bianca, and I'll be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] Please note that this conference is being recorded. 
I will now turn the call over to your host, Mr. John Locke. Mr. John, you may begin.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our
componenttext:
Good morning, and welcome to Valero Energy Corporation's First Quarter 2016 Earnings Conference Call. With me today are Joe Gorder, our Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Mike Ciskowski, our Executive Vice President and CFO; Lane Riggs, our Executive Vice President of Refining Operations and Engineering; Jay Browning, our Executive Vice President and General Counsel; and several other members of Valero's senior management team.
If you have not received the earnings release and would like a copy, you can find one on our website at valero.com. Also attached to the earnings release are tables that provide additional financial information on our business segments. If you have any questions after reviewing these tables, please feel free to contact our Investor Relations team after the call. 
I would like to direct your attention to the forward-looking statement disclaimer contained in the press release. In summary, it says that statements in the press release and on this conference call that state the company's or management's expectations or predictions of the future are forward-looking statements intended to be covered by the safe harbor provisions under federal securities laws. There are many factors that could cause actual results to differ from our expectations, including those we've described in our filings with the SEC.
Now I'll turn the call over to Joe for a few opening remarks.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. The first quarter presented us with challenging markets with gasoline and diesel margins under pressure for most of the quarter. The bright spot was the performance of our team, as we continue to operate saf
componenttext:
Well, thanks, John, and good morning, everyone. The first quarter presented us with challenging markets with gasoline and diesel margins under pressure for most of the quarter. The bright spot was the performance of our team, as we continue to operate safely and reliably. 
What I'd like to do this morning is take a few minutes to discuss our strategic initiatives that we believe will continue to drive long-term value creation and then share some color on what we're seeing in the markets. 
First is the core of everything we do, is the relentless focus on safety and reliability. Our dedication and persistence here is what keeps our people and communities safe, our operations reliable, our cash operating costs the lowest among the peer group. Having low-cost operations is a major advantage in our industry where product margins can be quite volatile. As a disciplined operator, we are able to run profitably in a lower margin environment as experienced in the first quarter. 
Second, we apply discipline and rigor as we evaluate and execute investments that will grow the profitability and competitiveness of our business for many years. The strategic plan that was approved by our Board of Directors last year included $2.6 billion of capital spending for 2016, approximately $1 billion was allocated to strategic investments to drive long-term earnings growth. 
Third, we're committed to delivering value to stockholders by making the right investments in our business and returning cash to our stockholders. We demonstrated this in 2015 when we delivered the highest total stockholder return among our peers for both Valero and VLP. We expect VLP to continue to be well positioned to execute its distribution growth strategy through 2017 despite volatile capital markets. 
We also continued to keep an eye on M&A. We review opportunities, and we have a list of targets that we consistently monitor. We consider M&A a discretionary use of cash, so there's a healthy tension when evaluating M&A opportunities versus other alternative uses. Of course, we can't comment specifically on M&A, but we are diligently reviewing opportunities. 
For cash returns in 2016, which is made up of dividends and buybacks, we've extended our 2015 payout target of 75% of net income. In January, we increased the quarterly dividend by 20% to $0.60 a share, and we remain focused on maintaining a dividend payout at the high end of our peer group. We're confident in Valero's ability to fund investments in future growth and to meet its payout target. 
Lastly, let me sure some color on the current market. Already this year, we've been in a lot of conversations about various market topics, including gasoline demand resurgence, octane strength, diesel length, domestic crude supply and crude storage levels. As you know, markets for Valero's feedstocks and products are dynamic. Our high complexity refineries, system flexibility, advantage locations and low cash cost operations enable us to maximize earnings under challenging market conditions. 
On the crude supply side, we're seeing more medium sour crudes coming into the market. As a result, we're seeing healthy medium and heavy sour crude discounts. We also have greater access to domestic sweet crudes with the logistics buildup in the U.S. allowing domestic production to clear the Mid-Continent region and reach the large Gulf Coast refining center. 
On the demand side, continued GDP growth and low product prices should continue to support demand. In the U.S., we've seen gasoline demand continue to grow. We're encouraged by increased vehicle miles traveled and double-digit percentage increases in SUV and truck purchases in the U.S. and key countries around the globe. 
Distillate demand globally was good, albeit in the U.S., it's been fairly flat. While distillate margins were pressured near term due to unseasonably warm weather in North America and Europe, distillate demand in Latin America remains robust. 
Overall, we still have structural refine product supply challenges in South America and in developing countries, which we don't expect to be resolved in the near term. With our low-cost Gulf Coast refining presence, we have the ability to compete in markets all over the globe. We also have the opportunity to optimize our system and supply, the Atlantic Basin with our refineries in Wales in Québec City. In fact, we generated another quarter of solid distillate and gasoline export volumes. 
In summary, we still have significant crude supply, ample natural gas availability and growing global petroleum demand that's outpacing refining capacity additions. We don't see this changing anytime soon. So although the markets will be challenging at times, the longer-term macro outlook remains favorable. 
So with that, John, I'll hand the call back to you.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Joe. Moving on to the results. Net income was $495 million or $1.05 per share for the first quarter of 2016. Excluding an after-tax, lower of cost or market inventory valuation benefit of $212 million or $0.45 per share, we recorded first quart
componenttext:
Thank you, Joe. Moving on to the results. Net income was $495 million or $1.05 per share for the first quarter of 2016. Excluding an after-tax, lower of cost or market inventory valuation benefit of $212 million or $0.45 per share, we recorded first quarter 2016 adjusted net income of $283 million or $0.60 per share. This compares to $964 million or $1.87 per share for the first quarter of 2015. For reconciliations of actual to adjusted amounts, please refer to Page 6 of the financial tables that accompany our release. 
Adjusted operating income for the refining segment in the first quarter of 2016 was $695 million or $946 million lower than in the first quarter of 2015. Margins were pressured downward primarily due to weaker distillate margins given high refinery run rates across the industry, product inventory builds and unseasonably warm weather. Other headwinds on refining margins included narrower domestic light sweet crude oil discount versus the Brent benchmark, low fuel oil and petrochemical product margins and elevated costs for RINs credits. 
Low crude oil prices continue to drive slowdowns in North American drilling and production, which, coupled with an excess of pipeline takeaway capacity in the Mid-Continent region, led to tighter discounts for crude oils relative to Brent. Low energy cost supported by robust North American natural gas production partly offset these factors. 
Our refineries operated at 96% throughput capacity utilization in the first quarter of 2016, and throughput volumes average 2.9 million barrels per day, which was 169,000 barrels per day higher than in the first quarter of 2015. Refining cash operating expenses of $3.55 per barrel were $0.40 per barrel lower than the first quarter of 2015, mostly due to higher throughput volumes and lower energy costs. 
The ethanol segment earned $9 million of adjusted operating income in the first quarter of 2016 compared to $12 million in the first quarter of 2015. The low crude oil and gasoline price environment challenged ethanol margins but with the recent recovery in prices, ethanol margins had modestly improved to start the second quarter. 
For the first quarter of 2016, general and administrative expenses, excluding corporate depreciation, were $156 million. Net interest expense was $108 million. 
Depreciation and amortization expense was $485 million, and the effective tax rate for the first quarter of 2016 was 30%. The effective tax rate was lower than the first quarter of 2015, primarily due to higher relative earnings contribution from international operations with lower statutory tax rates. 
Regarding our balance sheet, at quarter end, we had $7.3 billion of total debt and $3.8 billion of cash and temporary cash investments, of which $102 million was held by VLP. Valero's debt-to-capitalization ratio net of $2 billion cash was 20%. We had $5.5 billion of available liquidity, excluding cash, of which $575 million was only available to VLP. 
Cash flows in the first quarter included $479 million of capital investments, of which $161 million was for turnarounds and catalysts. 
For 2016, we expect to invest $1.6 billion of capital to sustain the business and $1 billion for refining asset optimization and logistics to drive long-term earnings growth. 
With respect to our refining growth strategy, the new Corpus Christi crude unit, which was completed late last year, operated as planned and delivered approximately $35 million of EBITDA in the first quarter. We completed the St. Charles hydrocracker expansion in March and the new Houston crude unit is on track to start up in the second quarter. The Houston alkylation project, which was approved in January, is now undergoing detailed engineering and procurement. Completion of the alkylation unit is expected on the first half of 2019. 
Now moving to the financing activities. We returned $547 million in cash to our stockholders in the first quarter, which included $282 million in dividend payments and $265 million for the repurchase of 3.8 million shares of Valero common stock. We have $1.1 billion of remaining share repurchase authorization as of March 31, 2016. Our regular quarterly cash dividend is now $0.60 per share. 
We continue to target a payout of 75% of annual net income for 2016. For modeling our second quarter operations, we expect throughput volumes to fall within the following ranges: Gulf Coast at 1.59 million to 1.64 million barrels per day; Mid-Continent at 430,000 to 450,000 barrels per day; West Coast at 260,000 to 280,000 barrels per day; and North Atlantic at 450,000 to 470,000 barrels per day. 
Refining cash operating expenses are estimated at approximately $3.75 per barrel for the second quarter. Based on today's market prices, we expect costs relating to meeting our biofuel blending obligations to be between $750 million and $850 million for 2015. This is primarily related to RINs in the U.S. The ethanol segment is expected to produce a total of 3.8 million gallons per day. 
Operating expenses should average $0.37 per gallon, which includes $0.05 per gallon for depreciation and amortization. G&A expenses for the second quarter, excluding corporate depreciation are expected to be approximately $165 million and net interest expense should be about $110 million. Total depreciation and amortization expense is estimated at $465 million and our effective tax rate is expected to be 31%. This concludes our opening remarks. [Operator Instructions]

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: I appreciate that guys. And then secondly, on the distillate market, you made a reference to the fact that it is tough out there in terms of the margins for distillates and part of that was weather, but part of it seems to be both supply and demand for th
componenttext: I appreciate that guys. And then secondly, on the distillate market, you made a reference to the fact that it is tough out there in terms of the margins for distillates and part of that was weather, but part of it seems to be both supply and demand for the product. How do you see that going forward for the balance of the year? And then can you talk about what you're seeing in terms of the export market for distillate and if that's ultimately the flywheel that can help rebalance the market?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Neil, this is Gary. Yes, I think what we've seen on distillate, we came out of winter with a lot of overhang in distillate inventories you alluded to. And then on the demand side, you get into March and demand was way off. Now we've certainly seen for the
componenttext: Neil, this is Gary. Yes, I think what we've seen on distillate, we came out of winter with a lot of overhang in distillate inventories you alluded to. And then on the demand side, you get into March and demand was way off. Now we've certainly seen for the past several weeks demand continue to creep up. We've seen some good agricultural demand begin to kick in. And so we've trended to where we're now more towards the 5-year high, actually last week, above the 5-year high. So I think some of these demand will help clean up the inventory. And then also, you talked about the exports. We're seeing a lot of good opportunities to export distillate as well. So the combination of 2 of those things, I think, will help keep domestic inventories in check. Moving forward, I think, if flat price continues to rise and start to see some recovery in the upstream sector, which should improved distillate demand as well. But really, we'll have to wait and see if we have a more normal winter this winter and that will be a key driver in terms of what happens with the distillate track from moving forward.

componenttext: I was hoping to get a little color on your thoughts around the drop-down targets. I believe you have $1 billion target. I think year-to-date, you've done about $240 million. But just in light of kind of some of the challenges we're seeing in the midstream, can you just share your thoughts around how you're thinking about that $1 billion target this year?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes, Blake. Sure, this is Mike. Before we get into that target, though, let me start off by talking about the capital markets. VLC does not need to execute any drop to meet its 25% disposition growth through 2017. So VLP does not need to access the capita
componenttext: Yes, Blake. Sure, this is Mike. Before we get into that target, though, let me start off by talking about the capital markets. VLC does not need to execute any drop to meet its 25% disposition growth through 2017. So VLP does not need to access the capital market. That being said, we believe the capital markets, both debt and equity, are open for MLP, particularly high-quality MLPs like VLP. The cost of issuing debt or equity, however, remains more expensive than historical level. The good news is VLP is well positioned with strong distribution company -- distribution coverage and does not need access to the capital market in this price environment. Therefore, we are going to revise our drop-down guidance to $500 million to $750 million. We can execute drops in this range without going to the capital market. We are going to continue to prepare for $1 billion in drops and will be ready to execute $1 billion in drop if the capital markets improve. From a Valero Energy perspective, regardless of whether or not we drop $500 million or $1 billion worth of assets this year to VLP, this amount will not materially change our view on our payout guidance.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay, Mike. That's helpful. The second question and this may tie in a little bit with Neil's M&A question, but the amount of, I guess, capital return to shareholders, $547 million, is well above your adjusted earnings. So you're obviously well on
componenttext: Got it. Okay, Mike. That's helpful. The second question and this may tie in a little bit with Neil's M&A question, but the amount of, I guess, capital return to shareholders, $547 million, is well above your adjusted earnings. So you're obviously well on track with that net income target. Obviously, 1Q is a little bit week, so maybe you see some improving earnings going forward. But I am just curious if you were to identify some M&A opportunities, does that materially change your thought on this 75% net income target?

componenttext: I would only say that we would have to look at that at the time of the acquisition. I mean, if there was a huge acquisition that might require some equity, then, obviously, we'd have to rethink about the buyback target. But it's going to be -- right now, I'm going to say no, but depending on the size of it, it could.

componenttext: And, Paul, I mean, you saw the cash balance that we got. As Mike said, we're very -- our leverage levels are very low, and we came through tough quarter with this balance sheet. So I think we're pretty well positioned. And I would tell you, though, if there was a significant M&A transaction out there, we would do the right thing as you would expect us to do and perhaps build some cash before we executed the transaction.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Okay. The second question, maybe this is for either Gary or Lane. In the first quarter, your system-wide margin capture rate versus your benchmark is about 62%. In the first quarter last year, it's about 70%. And your average in 2015, 2014 is about 72% an
componenttext: Okay. The second question, maybe this is for either Gary or Lane. In the first quarter, your system-wide margin capture rate versus your benchmark is about 62%. In the first quarter last year, it's about 70%. And your average in 2015, 2014 is about 72% and 67%. So just curious that in the first quarter this year, there are much lower margin capture rate. How much is related to just the different pricing and volume in the macro fund? And how much is related to more company-specific reasons? Any kind of insight would be great.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Paul, this is Gary. I can start with -- I guess it's hard to go into a lot of detail on the capture rates here. So certainly, I advice you to follow up with Karen and John after the call. But some high-level things I can tell in terms of volume variance,
componenttext: Paul, this is Gary. I can start with -- I guess it's hard to go into a lot of detail on the capture rates here. So certainly, I advice you to follow up with Karen and John after the call. But some high-level things I can tell in terms of volume variance, there really wasn't a negative impact on volume variance for our refineries. Actually, we would show that the volume variance was slightly positive for the quarter. So what you're seeing on the capture rate is all market-driven. In a  high level, there is a few things I would point to that higher-cost RIN certainly had an impact on our capture rates. The butane differential, the gasoline, was much more narrow in the first quarter than what we saw last year. That had an impact on our capture rates. In the North Atlantic Basin, when you look at our crude cost relative to Brent, the narrower Brent TIR impacted our crude cost, most importantly at Québec. Also, the Western Canadian crudes, the syn crudes, were more expensive in the first quarter, so the volumes coming of Line 9. So we had a crude cost impact to our North Atlantic Basin system. And the only thing that's really operationally, we had the Benicia crackdown on the West Coast for a planned turnaround, and so our capture rates there were down a little bit as well. But those are some of the real key factors.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: Gary, can I just have a quick follow-up? On the second quarter, your turnaround activity, is it focusing on the conversion unit, or that is crude unit?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016

componenttext: From JPMorgan, we have Phil Gresh.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: First question. On the Gulf Coast, your crude slate clearly shifted more towards mediums. In your slide deck, you have given a range historically for heavies of about 24% to 37% over time and you are at the low end of that range, 24%, in the first quarter
componenttext: First question. On the Gulf Coast, your crude slate clearly shifted more towards mediums. In your slide deck, you have given a range historically for heavies of about 24% to 37% over time and you are at the low end of that range, 24%, in the first quarter. And that was actually down year-over-year. So I know you talked about the medium and heavy discounts becoming available. We're there any onetime factors that led you to have, actually, lower heavies in the quarter? Or just generally, how are you thinking about crude slate as we progress through the year?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Phil, this is Gary. A couple of things. The way we report our results, we have the heavy sour crudes shown, but we also a category we show resids. And some of those resids are actually replacements for heavy sour crudes in our system. We run the resids th
componenttext: Phil, this is Gary. A couple of things. The way we report our results, we have the heavy sour crudes shown, but we also a category we show resids. And some of those resids are actually replacements for heavy sour crudes in our system. We run the resids through our crude unit. And so where the heavy sour crudes were down, actually the resids we process were up. So there really wasn't a significant difference in the amount of heavy sour crude we run in the first quarter. In terms of the range, some of the things that we talk about, it's not just the discounts that we're looking at, there's a rate lever associated with really pushing heavy sour crudes in our system. If we want to maximize heavy sour crudes, that generally mean we're running at lower throughputs. So we have to look at the discounts and also where the crack spreads are, and then we do that optimization.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Got it. Okay. A follow-up question just on the M&A front. With respect to refining to the extent you're looking there, could you just to remind us how you think about regionally where you want to be adding exposure?
componenttext: Got it. Okay. A follow-up question just on the M&A front. With respect to refining to the extent you're looking there, could you just to remind us how you think about regionally where you want to be adding exposure?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, if you look at areas that we feel that we could grow, okay -- and I'm doing this from just historical looks at different assets and how the FTC might do something, the West Coast, California in particular will be very, very difficult for us.
componenttext: Yes. I mean, if you look at areas that we feel that we could grow, okay -- and I'm doing this from just historical looks at different assets and how the FTC might do something, the West Coast, California in particular will be very, very difficult for us. We're not really focus there. The East Coast, we've exited, and so we're not interested there. The Mid-Con, I think we would be good to go on transactions and we'd be interested in there, and then, of course, U.S. Gulf Coast. And when we look at the acquisitions, we look at them from a perspective of where can we create the greatest synergies. And with the portfolio of assets that we have in the U.S. Gulf Coast, we believe that we can greet synergies around feedstocks and product movements there perhaps better than anywhere else. Now if we -- so that would be in the U.S. side. If we go over to Europe, I think we'd be interested in assets in markets like the U.K., where we've got a presence today and we could bolt something on and support it out of the London office. We're not interested in a lot of the countries in Western Europe just because of the nature of the assets and then the issues that go along with owning assets in those markets. And then I really think from our perspective, the Far East is off the table. So in a nutshell, the U.S. Gulf Coast would be interesting. The Mid-Con and then the U.S. would be interesting. The U.K. would be interesting, and that would be our primary focus.

Any shortages in any particular regions? And just how you look at that as we roll through the rest of the second quarter?

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: Roger, this is Gary. I think we're seeing very similar situations in regards to octane what we've seen in the last couple of years. Octane is starting to get tight, so we saw the rig rate in the Mid-Continent strengthen significantly. The premium rig rate
componenttext: Roger, this is Gary. I think we're seeing very similar situations in regards to octane what we've seen in the last couple of years. Octane is starting to get tight, so we saw the rig rate in the Mid-Continent strengthen significantly. The premium rig rate on the West Coast has also strengthened considerably in the last couple of weeks. So I think the industry is short octane, and we'll see similar rig rates to what we've been seeing in the past few years.

headline: Valero Energy Corporation, Q1 2016 Earnings Call, May 03, 2016
componenttextpreview: So no reason to think there is any sort of surplus octane out there at all at this point?
